characters: HANK SNOW, ROY ACUFF, MINNIE PEARL, BILL MONROE, LESTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down a mountain trail Loretta Webb, 13, rides a mule, whi is pulling a little wooden sled. On the sled is her broth Herman, 10, with a glob of white salve on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pitch black except for the miners' headlamps. Ted Webb, 4 drills a hand auger into the coal face. Powder is tapped -- "Fire in the hole!" -- and explosion. Miners crawl bac through the dust and shovel coal into a mule cart. A fore man shouts "Payday today, let's go!"" The miners shovel f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta and Herman move down the ridge toward the mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen miners come out of the mine, including Ted. His trousers are torn at the knees, which bleed slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta and Herman are waiting for Ted as he comes down t road.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Hi, Daddy -- boy, look at your knees, Daddy. Why ain't you a- wearin’ your kneepads?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Aw, Loretty, that ol' shaft is so low, if you wear your kneepads, you skin your back. Don't wear ‘em, you skin your knees, (grins) Wear ‘em tomorrow, I reckon. Give my back a turn. They continue on down the road. cs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A muddy red jeep flies over the ruts toward the company s driven by a young soldier with a plump, sexy girl beside The jeep careens into the storefront drive causing severa miners to leap out of the way, laughing and cussing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks at the salve on Herman's forehead. The little b jaws are clenched tightly shut.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: What you so sulled up about, Herman? What's that stuff on your head?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Herman's scared to open his mouth. We was playin' up by Prod Bottom and a ol' green snake bit him right on the head. Daddv, ain't it true that if a green snake bites you, you laugh yourself to death?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That's what I always heard.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: That thing bit Herman two hours ago. He's been clampin' his jaws shut ever since so he won't start laughin'. Ted looks at Herman and smiles to himself. Loretta sidles to Herman and says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Be careful, Herman. One little smile's liable to start it. And you'd just never stop. Herman glowers furiously at her. They are approaching ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young soldier ~- Doolittle Lynn, 19 -- holds forth co from the jeep as the girl, Lizzie, looks on. The others l as a jar of moonshine makes the rounds.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ps 5

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Boys, there ain't no place this thing can't take me -- no gully she can't jump, no creek she can't ford, no hill she can't climb.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MINER
dialogues.text: By God, I know one thing you can't climb -- that heap of red-dog past the mine up yonder.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hell, buddy, I can climb that damn mess backwards.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (going up steps with the kids) You boys watch your language with these children here. Doolittle salutes apologetically; Lizzie giggles. Ted glo and continues on to the pay window which is part of the s He gets in line. Loretta hangs back, listening.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Who wants to bet me I can't climb that red-dog?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MINER
dialogues.text: Backwards, you say?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hell, yeah, backwards! (to Loretta) ‘Scuse me, little girl. Backwards, right up to the top -- I got fifty dollars says I can do it! Who'll bet me? The others boisterously get up the money. Doolittle grins winks at Loretta. Flustered, she runs to Ted who is at th pay window getting paid in scrip.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Come on now. Let's get in the store and give the company their money back. Frowning in Doolittle's direction, Ted goes into the stor Loretta watches interestedly as Doo loudly covers all bet (ad lib). Then she goes in the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta watches the action outside through the front wind Ted is at the counter with the Storekeeper.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Who's that soldier boy out yonder struttin' like a banty rooster?

dialogues.speaker: STOREKEEPER
dialogues.text: That's ol' man Red Lynn's boy, Doolittle. Come back from the army just as wild as a hearthern. That Germany war's just ruint these mountains -- boys come back here don't want to do nothin' but cut shines and act wild.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: He'll calm down some when they slap a coal shovel in his hand. That Sears~Roebuck I ordered come in yet? Storekeeper nods and moves off to the rear. Loretta watch as out front Doolittle's jeep races off toward the mine, others scrambling after on foot, her eyes glowing with su excitement. Ted notes this.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Loretty -- get you a can of vy-annies for you and Herman. Her face lights up; she instantly forgets Doo and the jee gets a can of Vienna sausage from the shelf. The Storekee returns with a large brown mail-order package.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (eagerly) What's that, Daddy? Ted grins and says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the foot of the smoldering heap of waste Doo revs his as Lizzie and the others watch. A few of them are buying of moonshine from a man in a clump of trees nearby -- Lee Rainey, with a mule loaded down with bags of shine. Seein Ted, Loretta, and Herman approaching -- the mule-sled loa with groceries and the large package -- he waves and shou

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hey, Cousin Ted! Come here and get in on this bet -- it’s a sure thing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ps

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 7
dialogues.text: LEE (Cont'd) O1' Doolittle never get up there without rollin' over and killin' hisself! Ted comes up, nods. Lee grins at Loretta. She grins back is more interested in Doo and the jeep. Doo roars backwards up the red-dog pile, gets a little wa slips, slides, spins wildly -- showering burning ash on t spectators who scatter laughing. Then, just as he's about tip over, the tires catch and the jeep seems to spurt to top of the mound. The crowd cheers as Doo poses triumphan

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (whooping) Lord-a-mercy -- that sumbuck Doolittle don't know what quit means, does he?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (dryly) He sure went to a lot of trouble to get on top of a heap of trash. But Loretta is watching with bright, excited eyes....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted and the kids climb toward the cabin more kids burs from the house and run toward them -- Junior, 16; Jack, 1 Peggy Sue, 6; Donald Ray, 9. At the door is Clara, 35, ho Betty Ruth, 11 months. The kids converge on the package a Loretta races to a wooden well and begins drawing a bucke water.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You young'uns take that stuff in- side -~ and don't open that package til I get there. They rush inside with supplies. Loretta empties the water into a battered wash pan and Ted washes the coal dust off face and hands. Loretta waits with a towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids look on eagerly as Ted opens the package. Clara "Mommie" -- looks on from the kitchen door, holding the b

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pps 10 11

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 9
dialogues.text: The package is opened -- new shoes. Kids gasp happily and clamour for them.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Y'all kids hush -- you ain't a- touchin' them new shoes ‘till you washed them dirty feet. The kids all slam out of the house toward the well. Ted s Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Loretty -- try this on first. He takes a blue dress with little flowers out of the pack Loretta gasps happily -- races into the bedroom to try it

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Them others gonna be wantin' to know why she's a-gettin' treated so special.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Loretty's thirteen, Clary. She orta have her one dress that ain't made out of no flour sack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She undresses to her homemade underclothes. On the walls this room she shares with her parents, are plastered news and magazine pages -- with sepia photos of Loretta Young, Gregory Peck, Clark Gable, Scarlett O'Hara, visible. The kids are heard pounding back inside as she pulls on the n dress, thrilled and excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: putting on their new shoes, walking around looking at the feet, etc. Loretta enters in her new dress -- a size too

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Well, looky here. Right pretty, ain't it, Mommie?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: I reckon she'll grow into it fast enough.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: jm il 12 13 14

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTINUED ll

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How come she's a-gettin' a new dress?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Loretty's a woman, Jack. Women got to have pretty things to wear.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: Aw, she ain't no woman. She just a dad-burn kid. Herman laughs -- the other kids join in.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You're a-laughin', Herman. Reckon that's true about the green snake after all. Horrified, Herman remembers his snakebite. Loretta laughs and runs into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looks at herself in a tarnished mirror, primping in her t large dress, pulling the loose material as tightly across fledgling bosom as she can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee Rainey is working his moonshine still. Hearing a nois the bushes, he snatches up a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (from bushes) Lee Rainey! It's Doolittle Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Come on in here, Doo. I'se just about to blast you one. (gets a jar) Here, take you a sip. Rest your- self. ‘Member when you used to work for me, Doo? Sellin'’ my goods down't the mines?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I ‘member you used to pay me a nickle ever jug I sold.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: jm 14

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: How'd you like to come back and work for me again?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Not for no nickel a jug.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I'm talkin' about real money, Doo. Business is good, see. I'm sellin’ more whiskey than I can make.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I heard you been stealin' whiskey from them boys over in Greasy Creek.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Aw, just when I run shy of my own. They become aware of singing in the distance -- a girl's voice, young, clear, singing a mournful ballad: "I the Pines." Both men freeze and listen.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: That's my little cousin, Loretty Webb. She sits down there on her daddy's porch, a-singin' her little sister to sleep. I be up here workin' and hear her and I think, Lord, let me die if angels sing that sweet... : (beat) I'm fixin' to make me another run on Greasy Creek. You got that jeep, you know how to use a gun, and you need you a job. I'11 go fifty- fifty with you.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Sounds like a good way to get killed to me.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Doo, o1l' Uncle Nat Ramey used to say, if you born in the mountains, you got three choices: coal mine, moon- shine, or move it on down the line.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (gets up) I ain't sayin' no. But I gotta study on it first. He gives back the jar and goes into the woods.  jm 15 16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. RIDGESIDE - SUNSET is Doo looks down into the holler at Loretta in the porch sw with the baby, singing. He stands listening, thoughtfully to the sad ballad....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta tunes an old battery-powered Philco radio: Ernest Tubb's "“Walkin' the Floor Over You." At the table Clara upturns her coffee cup into the saucer and "reads" the gr as Loretta watches. The baby cries in a homemade cradle. comes in holding his head in pain; a bloody handkerchief his nose.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Don't run the batteries down on that radio, Loretty -- can't afford no new ones.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You got one of your bad headaches, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: I'll mix you up some medicine ---

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It don't do no good, nothin' does. Just this family weakness, have to suffer it.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Take the baby out and rock her, Loretty.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (getting baby) What do you see in the grounds, Mommie?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Woman cryin'. A man cryin', too.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Who are they? What are they cryin' about?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Clary, I swear it's bad enough you bein’ an ol' squaw medicine woman without makin' Loretty one, too.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: She's Indian much as me. We can see things other folks can't. Take the baby on out, Loretty. {looks back at grounds) Some bad times comin'....

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Don't need no fortune teller to know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta in the porch swing, sings to the baby: "I come to the garden alone, etc." Her clear voice soars up the ridge in the still morning air....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee Rainey on the run, pulling a mule loaded with stolen whiskey. His pistol in his hand, he looks behind him desperately. Then, hearing Loretta's voice, he stops, smiles. A twig snapping spins him around in terror ---

dialogues.speaker: POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: The sun shining down through the trees...shadowy figures among them...one of them raises a rifle....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta, singing, hears a shot ~- then a volley of shots. the ridge a flock of crows caw raucously. Loretta peers u the ridgeside. Silence. Emptiness. She stands on the porc clutching the baby, looking up, curious and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The face is caked with blood and dirt, the body riddled w

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: kt 20

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 20
dialogues.text: bulletholes. An old woman wails piteously nearby, pacing and down. The body is carried into the yard by several me including Doolittle. They lay the body on the-grass as Te Red Lynn, relatives and neighbors look on.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: He wanted me to go with him. I should've gone, I might could of helped him.... Others say nothing; stare at the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta cowering in Clara's arms, staring at the body. He eyes meet Doolittle's briefly; then Clara leads her insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doolittle looks up and sees Loretta; their eyes meet brie Then Clara leads her back inside.

dialogues.speaker: RED LYNN
dialogues.text: Maybe we orta get our guns and go visit Greasy Creek.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) It wasn't nothin' but Lee's craziness caused this. Hadn't a'been this, it'd been another thing.

dialogues.speaker: RED LYNN
dialogues.text: (to Doolittle) Good thing you wasn't still a-workin' for him, son. ‘You'd be layin' there aside him. (beat) ‘Course if you'd been workin' for

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: kt 21

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 21
dialogues.text: RED LYNN (Cont'd) Lee at least you'd a-been workin' somewheres.” af Red cackles; the others frown. Doo looks thoughtfully at the corpse. ‘ - .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explosion: Smoke clears. A miner crawls through it: It is Doolittle. He begins shovelling coal into the mule cart. looks trapped and frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wintertime; a light coat of snow on the little school. In it's brightly decorated for Christmas. A fiddle and banjo guitar play "Cumberland Gap." Several horses are tied out Doo drives up in his jeep, parks, goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cakewalk in progress (like musical chairs), with Lorett playing. Doo enters and spots her right away; she is very pretty in her new dress -- which now fits nicely. Doo decides he's going to meet her. He ambles near a table wi several pies on it, with name cards. One is Loretta's. Nearby, a Churchwoman is talking distraughtly to the Teac a sour-faced chain-smoking man.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHWOMAN
dialogues.text: Preacher Banks was supposed to auction off these pies for the girls, but he's sick and I can't do it ---

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Well, I sure ain't got time to auction no pies! Besides, if them girls wants a boy to eat a

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 23
dialogues.text: TEACHER (Cont'd) pie with ‘em, they'll do it auction or not! He stalks off. Churchwoman looks desperate.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hey, lady? I'11 auction off your pies for you.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHYVIOMAN
dialogues.text: (great relief) You will? The Lord'll bless you for this, son.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (glancing at Loretta) Maybe he will. Never can tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the pie table.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Six bits, six bits, who'll gimme a dollar -- dollar once, dollar twice -- sold to the man for a dollar. He's enjoying being center of attention. A boy collects a pie and a girl, and Doo picks up Loretta's pie. She watch nearby, blushing.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Got one more left, a chocolate pie here, belong to Loretta Webb -- who's gonna bid first? A large boy named Flop Murphy. looks bashfully at Loretta

dialogues.speaker: FLOP
dialogues.text: I bid two bits.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Two bits? Man, that's a insult. Who'll start it off for a dollar?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: pl 24

dialogues.speaker: FLOP
dialogues.text: (waits; no one bids) I guess I get it then.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I bid a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: FLOP
dialogues.text: You the auctioneer -- you ain't supposed to bid.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Dollar once, dollar twice ---

dialogues.speaker: FLOP
dialogues.text: (hastily) Hey -- dollar'n a dime!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Three dcllars.

dialogues.speaker: FLOP
dialogues.text: That ain't fair -- he's cheatin'! As Doo says "once, twice," FLOP ° Three and a dime!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Three seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: FLOP
dialogues.text: (in agony) Three seventy...seven.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Five dollars. Flop flops heavily into a chair, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Once, twice, sold to Mr. Doolittle Lynn for five dollars. Crowd applauds; Doo claims the pie and Loretta -- slightl dazed, blushing furiously -- and gces to a corner where h cuts a piece with a pocket knife.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (rattling nervously) Ain't nobody ever paid five dollars for a pie before, I bet. Mommie said,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LORETTA (Cont'd) girl, ain't nobody gonna buy a pie off you cause everybody knows you can't cook no better 'n a day-old heifer. Wait'll I tell her, she just gonna die! Five dollars! She watches expectantly as Doo takes a large mouthful. As chews, his eyes bug out, he chokes, he gets to his feet a looks around desperately. Loretta watches in alarm as he frantically throws open a window, thrusts his head out an spews out the pie. He then grabs a pitcher of lemonade an washes his mouth out.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You made a lotta chocolate pies before?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (nervously) Not too many...'cept for that one.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: How much salt does your recipt call for?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Shoot, you don't use no salt in a chocolate pie -- just sugar, and (beat) Oh, no....

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Guess you got ‘em mixed up. Under- standable, they both bein' white and all.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (moaning) Oh, no...! You gotta get your five dollars back.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I don’t want no five dollars back. I just want you. (she looks alarmed) I mean, I want to take you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo leads Loretta to his jeep.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: pl 25

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: No use walkin' when you can ride. Get in.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (looks at jeep nervously) I ain't gettin’ in that thing.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You ain't never even rode in a car before, have you? I be damn.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) That thing ain't no car anyway -- looks like somethin' come from Mars.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What do you know about Mars? Bet you ain't never been past the foot of the holler. Come on, get in ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I said I ain't gettin' in that thing and I ain't! You just walk it home if vou think so much of it!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (slightly taken back) Whoo. You pies ain't the only thing salty about you, is they? Let's walk then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk, Doo holding a pine-torch. Below them the mine brightly lit as the night shift works.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I had my eye on you a long time. I told myself, sooner or later me and that little gal's gonna get together. . Loretta, thrilled, gropes desperately for a response, but nothing comes out. Doo goes on.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You're different from the rest of ‘em around here. Special. Like me. The kind of person that's gotta have more out of life.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: om” ps

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: .--More what...?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: More'n what Butcher Holler's got to offer. (indicates mine) More'n this.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (trying to flirt) I saw you, too. In that little ol' soldier suit. I thought, he looks just like a little toy soldier.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (angry) Listen here -- I joined the army to feed my Mamma and nine brothers and sisters. I went ashore at D~Day plus four and I'se in combat til the day the war ended. I wasn’t no little toy soldier, lady. Frightened by this outburst, Loretta draws back. Doo glow at her a moment, then grins. They walk on.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: They walk slowly toward the lights of the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: The army showed me it's a whole big world out yonder -- and I ain't about to spend my life buried in no damn coal mine. Ain't a damn bit of future in it. That's what I'm interested in -- the future. What's your plans for the future?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Ain't got none that I know of. (beat) You sure cuss a lot, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cuss, drink, and chase after wild women. Suddenly he pulls her toward him; she's alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What're you doin' --

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Fixin' to kiss you goodnight. You ever been kissed before? She hasn't; quickly decides she likes it. They do it agai They break, Doo grins, hands her the torch, she awkwardly for the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: . DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I'll bring my jeep up here and take you for a ride.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (breathless) You'll never get that thing up the holler.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: There ain't nothin' I can't do, once I put my mind to it. She smiles uncertainly, rushes into the cabin. Pleased wi himself, Doo turns jauntily and smacks into a fence post, careens downhill through bush and stones, splashes into a rushy creek where he lies moaning but happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara, making lye soap; Loretta dreamily adding wood to t fire beneath the rendering kettle. Ted is plowing with th mule in the garden, A shout from down the holler’.(from Junior): “Stranger comin' up!" followed by a shout from Herman a little closer; “Stranger comin'!" Everybody stop working and looks toward the trail: A faint sound, an eng straining uphill...Loretta recognized it's Doo's jeep, he face lights up...The rest of the family looks puzzled, a frightened, as the sound gets louder and closer...Suddenl Herman and Junior burst through the foliage into the yard ling and pointing behind them where --- Doolittle's jeep seems to leap out of the foliage and int yard. He stops proudly, his face bruised and cut from las night's accident.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Told you I could make it up here. Now you're gonna take a ride with me!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 27
dialogues.text: Loretta excitedly clambers in -- and Doo roars off instan before Ted and Clara can make a move or speak. Ted is fur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta hangs on, frightened and excited, as Doo speeds d the bumpy mountain trail. She looks at his battered face.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What happened -- was you in a fight?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Yeah -- me and this fence post got into it.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What? Doo just laughs. They speed up a steep mountain road, pas slow-moving coal trucks; through the drab streets of Van now decorated for Christmas, with people staring. Loretta gets more and more excited and breathless until:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: screeches to a halt. Loretta looks down at the drop, exci dizzy. Doo grabs her and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I can't breathe...I feel like I'm a-gonna faint....

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: That's how you're supposed to feel when you're in love.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: It is...? They kiss again; she throws her arms around his passionat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sits grimly, a willow switch in his hand, watching the do Clara and the other children are all there, waiting...Lor comes in. Stops guiltily, seeing them:

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mw 30

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Where you been, Loretty...?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doolittle...took me ridin'....

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You just run off. Didn't ask or nothin'.... He begins switching her around the legs; she whimpers and tries to hop out of the way; the other children scatter. has tears in his eyes, hating what he's doing. Finished, breaks the switch and goes into his bedroom. Loretta is d up in a corner, rubbing her legs, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: (to other children) Y'all get to bed -- right now. They quickly vanish. Clara examines the welts on Loretta' legs.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: (continuing} Don't you know he'd rather cut his arm off than to whip you? What did you mean, runnin' off like that with that wild boy?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTE
dialogues.text: (sobbing) I love him, Mommie.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA . -
dialogues.text: (angrily) You don't do no such thing. I'11 mix you some salve for your legs. {starts for kitchen) You stay away from Doolittle, Lynn -- or I'll give you worse what your Daddy did. Clara exits. Loretta sniffles miserably, but a faint look defiance is in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family sits listening as Clara reads the Nativity sto

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 31
dialogues.text: from the Bible (Luke 2ff). Loretta hears Doo's jeep pull outside; then his footsteps on the porch and knock on the door. She watches Ted nervously as he answers.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Evenin' Mr. Webb. Loretty here?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: We're havin' our family Christmas, Doolittle.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Yessir. I just brought this present for Loretta, and if she'll step out here. I'll just give it to her and go. Ted hesitates, then nods. Loretta runs eagerly onto the porch as Clara resumes reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss. Doo gives her a package -- she opens it -~ it contains a large doll baby.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (angrily) What are you givin’ me this for? You think I'm just a little kid or somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: That's just for now. '

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I mean by next Christmas, me and you'll have us a real little doll. She looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Me and you is gonna be married pretty soon.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 32
dialogues.text: He kisses her, grins, jumps off the porch and runs back t jeep. Loretta stands incredulous, holding the doll...Insi Clara continues reading the Bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: leads the male and sled; Loretta follows with a carbide l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vein of coal in the mountainside which families have tunnelled into over the years for their private coal. Lor holds the lamp while Ted chops the coal. Everything is bl except their two faces, close together.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Loretty, you know I don't like to boss you, don't you? But I got to, now.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Daddy ---

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Just lemme talk. I don't want you to see Doolittle no more. You promise me that.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I can't, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (chopping at the coal) You're just a little girl. He's a growed-up man -- a wild one.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I love him, Daddy -- he's a-wantin' me to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (shocked) You ain't even fourteen yet. Y'all ain't even knowed each other a month ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I know, but I just love him.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Lord, Lord, don't do this, Loretty -- don't throw all your young years away. I worked hard all my life, got very little to show for it except you. You're my pride, girl, my shinin' pride ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (tearfully) I just can't help it, Daddy --- Ted can't speak; chops at coal face, jaws clenched shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: assembled. Loretta aloof from the others, sad and depress Ted tunes the Philco to a familiar voice:

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: From the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, Tennessee, this is the Solemn O1' Judge speakin' and this is the Grand Ole Opry -- let ‘er rip, boys! Bill Monroe and his Bluegrass Boys cut loose with "Blue M of Kentucky." Ted claps his hands, trying to cheer Lorett up.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Get up and do your squaw dance, Mommie ~- see if you can't get a smile out of ol’ sourpuss here --- Clara hesitates, then throws down her sewing and does an energetic hoedown. The others clap and shout. Ted watches Loretta but she remains sadly aloof. Suddenly, the door o and Doolittle steps in, awkwardly. Everything stops.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I knocked, but reckon y'all couldn't hear me. Loretta runs to him, instantly happy. Ted looks at her; s _ thing seems to drain out of him. He clicks off the radi goes out onto the porch. Clara goes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Looks like I broke up the party.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (takes his hand) Don't matter. Come here and sit down --- The other kids begin to giggle.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mw o~ 35 ao 36

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Y'all get outta here or I'm gonna smack the tar outta ever one of you! They scatter in various rooms, sniggering and smirking.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (as they sit on the sofa) Look here at this. He pulls out a wad of money.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: My gosh -~ where'd you get all that?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Paycheck. Been savin’ 'em. You know what tomorrow is? Our anni- versary. Loretta spots Herman making a face around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Herman, I'm gonna kill you! She leaps up and smacks him hard, chasing him around the until he can escape into the kitchen. Then she returns to the sofa,

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What was you a-sayin', Doo?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I said tomorrow is our anniversary -- we met a month ago tomorrow. I think it'd be a good day for us to get married. Specially since I just got all this money.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (stunned) You'll...you'll have to ask Daddy.... Doo nods and goes out on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is hunkered on the steps, smoking a cigarette. Doo com up.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Uh, Mr. Webb...? I'm fixin' to marry Loretty. If it's all right with you. Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTINUED 3€

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: {also stunned; long pause) Go ask Clary. INT. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT’ ~ LORETTA 37 watches as Doo comes back in and crosses to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sits reading the coffee grounds in her saucer.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Miz Webb, me and Loretty want to get married, tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: (pause) Go ask Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees Doo cross back out to the front porch. Her broth and sisters continue tormenting her as she waits in suspe After a moment Doo comes back and starts for the kitchen

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doolittle, what are you doin?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Aw, Ted says ask Clara and Clara says ask Ted and ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Come here. Just sit down and wait till they go to bed, then you can catch 'em together. Else, they'll keep you runnin' back and forth all night. Doo sits with a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are half asleep on the couch when Ted and Clara fina start getting ready for bed. When they are both under the covers, Doo comes to the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Mister-Miz Webb, I know how you feel. Everything's happened real fast. And I know she's young, and I know how much y'all love her. But the deal is, I love her, too -- as much you do. I seen a lot of the world and I growed up pretty fast, but the minute I seen Loretta, I knew she was all I'd want in this life. And I swear to you -- I'll bust my back workin’ to make her happy.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Reckon you're set on it, no matter what we say.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I don't wanna go against y'all, Miz Webb, but...yeah. We're set on it.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You promise me two things, boy. Don't you never hit her. And don't you take her off far from home.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I promise you that. He goes. Through the door he can be seen kissing Loretta night. Then she comes in to get ready for bed.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Mommie, Daddy -- I'm so happy I don't think I'm gonna be able to sleep! (silence) Are y'all still awake? An odd, muffled sound from their bed; both are crying sof Loretta stands in the dark, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Judge performs the ceremony in the cold empty courtroom Angie Lynn, Doo's mother is there, a few others, but no C or Ted. As the ceremony goes on, Loretta looks around for them. Ted comes in at last, doesn't sit, leans on the wal the rear.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Who gives this woman to be wed? Loretta looks around at Ted. After a long pause, he nods,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: {to Doo) Do you have the ring?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I ain't got no ring, Judge. Judge pronounces them man and wife. They kiss. Loretta lo up just in time to see Ted duck out the door....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo's jeep with a canvas cover pulls up in front of one o plain wood cabins. He and Loretta jump out -- it's freezi cold -- and dash for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to a radiator and turns it on. Loretta in a teddy bear coat stands shivering. Doo flips his suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: She'll warm up in a minute. Hey -- I got a present for you from Mama. He tosses her a nightgown, then goes into the bathroom. S ering with fear and cold, she sits on the radiator, clutc the nightgown. Hearing the toilet flush, she looks mortif In a moment Doo comes out in his undershirt and army skiv She quickly averts her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (indicating bathroom) Go on and get ready for bed, baby. She nods numbly and goes in as Doo turns back the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are out, Doo waits in bed, she steps cautiousl of the bathroom, in the nightgown, and gets into bed. Doo embraces her, then:

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: {laughs, says tenderly) Loretta? You ain't supposed to put your nightgown on over your clothes.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'm freezin', Doo.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (patiently) Go on back in the bathroom and take off everything but your gown. Go on, now. Embarrassed, she goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She clicks on the light and we see how completely scared is, She dutifully removes all clothing from beneath her g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes and gets into bed again. Doo moves....

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doo -- hey, don't, that ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Take it easy now, just relax ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: No ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Relax, now -- first time’s a little rough sometimes. Just hang on. She struggles. Sound of gown being ripped ~- thrown out o on the floor. It is a rape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with a breakfast tray, slipping in the snow, goes into --  ps 47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sits in bed in her teddy bear coat, miserable. The door o and Doo comes in with a tray which he brings to her. She looks at the congealed ham and eggs.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: This stuff's cold.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: That's because by the time I can carry it back here from the restau- rant, it's damn near froze. From now on, you're goin' with me.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I ain't goin' in that restaurant, have all them people lookin' at me, knowin' what we been doin' in here.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hell's bells, Loretta, you think this is somethin' the rest of the world ain't caught on to yet? They don't give a damn. (softens) Aw, look, baby. I told you the first time was a little rough.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Sure didn't seem like it was rough on you.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Well you better learn to like it. Because that's what marriage is all about.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I ain't never gonna like you gettin’ on me and a-sweatin' and --- He slaps her; she jerks back, more startled than hurt.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You promised Daddy you wouldn't hit me and look at you already!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Aw, hell. I'm sorry. But you drove me to it.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You're pushin' me too fast! You just gotta gimme a little time, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 47
dialogues.text: She gets up and storms into the bathroom, slamming the do Dispiritedly, Doo jabs at the congealed egg yolks with a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sits slumped against the wall; finishes a sandwich, start another. Three other miners nearby.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MINER
dialogues.text: Ol' Doo must be pregnant. He's been eatin' enough for two lately.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MINER
dialogues.text: Hell, Doo don't need to have no babies. He married him one. Doo instantly jumps the miner: the others laugh and jeer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest, weatherbeaten house. Doo pulls up in his jeep, grimy with coal dust, he goes inside. He has a small pack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sitting at the table, looking at a newspaper. Smiles at D who comes in glowering, looks into a pot of beans steamin the stove, shakes his head sadly.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Hi, hon. Looky here at this. {indicates newspaper) These radios are on sale cheap. You reckon we could get us one? He says nothing, tosses the package in front of her. She it eagerly: a book, "Sex for Newlyweds." She opens the bo her eyes go wide.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: My gosh...it's got pictures in it...!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: That book's supposed to've helped millions of couples the world over. Thought it might help us.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (turning pages) I can't read this thing, Doo,..It's got all these big words in it...Like look here at this one: that doggone word's a foot long, Doo! What in the world could a foot long word mean?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED A9-A
dialogues.text: Doo gives her a discouraged look. Goes to the pantry, pul out a bottle of whiskey, takes a healthy drink.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Aw, Doo...I don't need no book to tell me what's wrong. You just need to be a little more gentle and patient with me, honey. You just got to give me a little more time....

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Give you a little time...Lemme add up how many things I'm supposed to give you a little time on; a little time to learn how to cook; a little time to learn how to clean the damn house; a little time to learn how to love your man the way you're supposed to -- dad-dammit, woman, is there anything you know how to do right now? Pause: She sighs and looks down at her hands -- which rem her:

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doo? When you gonna get around to gettin' me a weddin' ring? Doo stares at her, can't believe. Starts pulling on his jacket, making a low, threatening, gutteral growl....

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Are you a-makin' that noise...? Sound like a ol' bear or something’. (sees him starting out) Doo, where you goin'? Are you a- leavin'?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (stops short) Naw. I ain't leavin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at the old washing machine in the yard, Ted in the garden They look up to see Loretta coming up the trail with her little suitcase. They run to greet each other.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doo throwed me out, Mommie.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Thank the Lord. Thank the Lord! Maybe it ain't too late to save you from ruinin' your life!

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (coming up) What in the world -- Loretty! Have you come back home? She laughs as he swings her around happily.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Lord, girl -- look at you! I believe married life done made you fat! Clara's smile fades abruptly; she looks closer at Loretta stomach.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: (sinking feeling) Oh, Lord, no....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc Turner, 30, pulls on rubber gloves as Loretta, a shee wrapped around her, climbs on an examination table. boc Last time I seen you I was givin' you a shot for the chicken pox. Now you're an ol' married woman, How you like it?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Fine, doc. But...me and Doo is separated. boc Things happen pretty fast with you and Doolittle, don't they? Doc begins his examination. Loretta is so embarrassed she pulls the sheet over her head. He smiles to himself, begi the examination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: comes out and starts walking home, miserable. She begins sniffle, then cry -- and suddenly she sees ---

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 53
dialogues.text: -- Doolittle's jeep pulled up at the curb down the street his back to her. Leaning suggestively on the jeep, talkin and smiling, is Lizzie. Enraged, Loretta picks up a stick and runs to the jeep.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doolittle Lynn -- what's this sow doin' a-wallerin' all over your jeep!

dialogues.speaker: LIZZIE
dialogues.text: What'd you call me?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: A sow -- which is a woman pig! Loretta swings the stick. Lizzie makes a quick retreat, w Loretta right after. Doo watches apprehensively as Lorett starts back for him. He steels himself for the blows, but she walks right past him. He jumps out and runs after.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Loretta, wait a minute -~- I was just comin' to see you ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Was you a-gonna bring your girl friend with you?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Aw, she just flagged me down, it didn't mean nothin'. I got some- thin' to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I got somethin’ to tell you, too.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I'm leavin' Kentucky, Loretta. She stops dead, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I'm goin' out west, to Washington. Get me a job on a ranch or somethin'. That coal mine's buryin' me alive, Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You was just gonna leave me...?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mw 53

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Just long enough to get set up, then I'll send you the money to join me.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What makes you think I'm gonna come?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You're my wife, baby.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'm your wife! Boy, you better think of a better reason than that! Maybe Mommie and Daddy's right, maybe I ain't ready for no marriage -~ but if what we got is a marriage, I'd just as soon not have one noways.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Aw, you're right. Maybe we should've waited, I don't know. Deal is, I loved you too much to wait. I love you too much to lose you now. If we could just start over, away from our families, and -~ there ain't nothin' for me here, Loretta, nothin! but a chestful of coal dust and bein' a old man by the time I'm forty. And it's so pretty out in Washington. I was there as a kid, pickin' fruit. You gotta come with me.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You promised Daddy you wouldn't take me off from home....

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You gotta make up your mind, Loretta -7 where you're his daughter or my wife. Come on. I'll drive you home. What was you doin' down here anyways?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I came to see Doc Turner.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You ain't sick, are you?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'm gonna have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (stunned, pleased) Well, I be damned...You know, maybe you finally found somethin' you know how to do. They drive towards the holler in the jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta's brothers and sisters play an energetic game of in the yard. Loretta sits on the steps, watching. Her stomach is very large now. She watches the children with sad thoughtful expression as if knowing her childhood is forever. Ted comes up the trail in his work clothes. He, too, has sad expression. He somberly hands Loretta a letter -- her face lights up instantly. She tears it open and some mone falls out. Clara comes onto the porch and she and Ted wat sadly as Loretta eagerly reads the letter:

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: He's sent for me...Doo's sent me the money to come to Washington...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small station, deserted platform, except for Ted and Lore with her suitcase and a sack lunch. Ted walks to the edge a platform and looks up at the empty tracks.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: She's late...Reckon she might of jumped the tracks up the line some- wheres.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (nervously) Aw, them trains don't do that

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Been known to.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mw #02119 36 oo, 54-A CONTINUED 54-A Ted paces, Loretta watches him. He stops at the scales.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Get on here. See what you weigh. k

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (she does) A hunnerd and seventeen! ‘This baby's gonna be a big ‘un, ain't it, Daddy? You weigh now.

dialogues.speaker: TED .
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Wouldn't do no good. I wouldn't , know how much was me and how much ® was all that coal dust I swallered. He looks up: the train appears down the tracks. ‘ LORETTA (suddenly throws her arms around him) Oh, Daddy. Don't be sad. I gotta ~~ be with Doo -- I'm fixin' to have his baby. I'm growed up now, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I ain't never gonna see you again.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: “ Yes, you will, Daddy! I'11 come and visit as much as I can -~ me and Doo and the baby. And you and Mommie can come and visit us.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Maybe. But I ain't never gonna see My little girl again. Them years has been robbed from me. Just like a thief broke in and : robbed 'em.... He tolds her tightly, trying to keep from erying. The train noisily pulls into the station.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY WELLS' RECORD 55
dialogues.text: of "It Wasn't God "Who Made Honky Tonk Angels." Pulling b slowly, we see the yellow is the dial face of a Zenith ta model radio; we hear Loretta singing along with the recor Panning slowly we see we are in a modest kitchen; we pass (1) a window -- it's raining hard outside; (2) a gas stov with boiling kettle full of mason jars; (3) another pot f of boiling apples; (4) Loretta, stirring the pot, singing holding a three-year-old girl in her arms, Cissy.... Continuing the pan we see (5) four-year-old Ernest Ray on the floor; (6) five-year-old Jack Benny nearby; and (7) six-year-old Betty Sue at the kitchen table. They all pla boisterously around the kitchen as Loretta cooks and sing to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the pouring rain, Doo drives a D-4 Caterpillar down a woodec trail, dragging a large log on a chain. Two other Loggers are trying to keep dry in the cab of a truck near

dialogues.speaker: FIRST LOGGER
dialogues.text: (shouts at Doo) Hey, Mooney! Let's dog off! It's rainin' if you ain't noticed!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hell, it's always rainin' out here. I ain't gonna melt.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND LOGGER
dialogues.text: I thought hillbillies was supposed to be lazy.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST LOGGER
dialogues.text: Not that one. That sunbitch never stops workin'. Doo expertly spins the Cat in the mud, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small wooden house on the edge of a large field. Anothe larger farmhouse in the distance. Doo pulls up in the yar ina '55 Ford. The kids come out to meet him and they all go inside.  58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still cornbread and beans, but cooked to perfection now. The whole family at the table, Doo eating with gusto.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Pass your daddy some more cornbread, Jack Benny.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What'd you do today, baby?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I put up seventeen quarts of apple butter. And -- Ernest Ray stop makin' that noise -- and all that rain made the doggone sink stop up ~~ stop a-hittin' him, Jack Benny -- and I spent half the mornin' a- fixin' that and -- dad blame it, I'm gonna smack the jaws off both of y'll -- and then I had this doctor's appointment --- Deo looks up with alarm,

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: 7-~ and he said it was just a false alarm but we better start bein' a whole lot more careful -- wipe your chin off, Betty Sue. And then I come home and fixed supper and I'm "bout ready to die. And how was your day?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Wet. He grins and goes on eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo wanders out, smoking, into the adjointing field to relieve himself. From the farmhouse across the field, a man's voice shouts over:

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey, Mooney -- !

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Yo!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mw

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Your mama called long distance from Kentucky today -- said Happy Anniversary and why don't you call her sometime?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Much obliged.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Why don't you have a phone put in sometime, Mooney?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I don't like telephones. He starts back for the house, hears Loretta singing a sad ballad, "The Great Titanic."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo in the doorway, listening to Loretta sing to the chil

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I just rememberd we got an anniversary comin' up, baby. What kind of present you want?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I still ain't got no weddin’ ring.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (indicates kids) Hell, woman, if you don't know you're married by now, you ain't never gonna know. She gives him a look, resumes singing. Doo listens, a ver thoughtful expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some working men lounging at the door of a tavern. Doo, getting off from work, pulls up, waves, goes to the windo of a nearby jewelry-pawn shop, looks at the display of wecding-engagement rings. Then his eye goes to a row of guitars....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: asleep. Doo comes in carrying a guitar, turns on the ligh plops down on the bed. Loretta's eyes are open.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Happy anniversary, baby.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Looks like you had a happy anniversary. You somethin', Doo? Most couples celebrates their anniversaries together. (sees guitar) What's this thing?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: It's your present. Happy anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: My present -- ? Sometimes I think you're missin' a washer in your brain, Doo -- I can't play this thing ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Most people can't without they learn how first. You ain't too ignorant to learn, are you? If you don't want it, I'll bust it up for firewood ~- give it here....

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: {grabs it away) Don't you do no such a thing! (beat) Boy. I never know what you're gonna do next. I just don't under- Stand why you got me a guitar ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Because when I was listenin' to you singin' to the babies I thought, Loretta sings a helluva lot better'n any them women on the radio. She orta have her a guitar.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I didn't know you ever paid any attention to me singin'. You really think I sing good?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: m™w 61

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: That's what I said, ain't it? (clicks out light, puts arm around her) Now. What kind of present you got for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta trying to master a G-chord as an old washing mach chugs next to her. The kids run around playing nearby. Sh concentrates hard. The washing machine gets stuck and mak an awful grinding sound. Without missing a beat Loretta kicks the machine hard. It resumes working and she resume practicing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guitar continues from previous scene but a little improve now. She sits on the sofa, playing and singing "Cold Cold Heart" to the kids on the floor, playing audience. INT. KITCHEN - NIGHT 61-c Singing and playing (still more improved) continues. Doo and the kids eat supper, listening. Doo is very thoughtfu again....

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hey. How bout Saturday night we get us a baby-sitter and go out somewheres.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (stops playing) You mean together?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hell, yes, together. Keep on playin'. Sounds good. She resumes playing, he resumes eating....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both dressed for a night out. Doo pulls up in front of th Grange Hall with a mysterious grin.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Vihat do you keep grinnin’ about...? Vhat're you up to? Doolittle says nothing. They go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Steel Guitar Rag” being played by the Westerneers, a loc band. The hall is packed with noise and smoke. Doo deposi Loretta at a table and goes for drinks at the bar. She si watching the people as a slick cowboy comes up grinning.

dialogues.speaker: SLICK
dialogues.text: How bout a dance, darlin'?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Uh...I can't. I'm married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must not be too married. You ain't wearin' no ring. Loretta embarrassedly covers her hand. Doo returns and Sl moves off. Loretta looks miserably at her ring finger and suddenly brightens:

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Hey! I bet I know what that surprise is!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (winks) You guessed it, huh? You wait right here and I'll go fix it up. He moves off towards the bandstand. Puzzled, she sees him corner the bandleader, John Penn, and start talking energ cally, gesturing in her direction. Suddenly she realizes what he's doing and panics. Doo beckons her to the band- stand; she shakes her head frantically. He frowns and sta for her. She leaps to her feet, truly frightened, and rus through the crowd, heading for the ladies room. Doo pushe his way through the crowd, searching for her. He bumps in Slick, talking to a pal.

dialogues.speaker: SLICK
dialogues.text: (winking) Keep your eyes open, hoss. Lotta

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 63
dialogues.text: SLICK (Cont'd) married stuff here tonight done took off their rings. Doo sees Loretta heading into the ladies room and follows

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the small room, two Ladies are startled as Loretta rus in, looking as if she's about to be sick.

dialogues.speaker: PIRST LADY
dialogues.text: You all right, honey? You look sick.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND LADY
dialogues.text: Maybe she's pregnant...Are you expectin', honey? Doo suddenly slams the door open; the two Ladies are trap in the corner and watch wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you? Why'd you run off like that?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Don't make me get up there and sing, Doo, please -- I'm sick, Doo!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Aw, you ain't gonna sing. That ol' boy wouldn't allow it.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (relieved) Thank the Lord...!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: But he said he'd listen to you tomorrow. Turns out they need a singer’real bad} so tomorrow, you're gonna go audition for ‘em ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (panics again) I ain't no singer, Doo! I can't sing for no strangers!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Yes, you can. I done fixed it all up for you.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You didn't ask me nothin' about it ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: How could I when you was runnin' off and hidin' like a stupid hill- billy.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (furious) Don't you call me no stupid hill- billy! I may be ignorant, but I ain't stupid! Why are you wantin' me to sing so much, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: {calmly) Because I'm proud of you when you sing. I want everybody to know how proud of you I an.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (melting) Oh, Doo...I'm glad I make you proud, but, I can't sing in front of people. I just can't....

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You damn sure can and you're damn sure goin' to -- and you're gonna sing for them boys tomorrow and next week you're gonna be singin’ right here if I have to kick your stupid hillbilly butt ever inch of the way! He slams the door hard; the two Ladies jump; Loretta look sick again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta still looks sick, at the edge of the bandstand in home-made western dress, holding her guitar. She can't br herself to look at the large, rowdy audience. On stage th Westerneers finish "Take Me Back to Tuisa."

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PENN
dialogues.text: Now, folks, y'all give a big welcome to the newest addition to the Westerneers, Miss Loretta Lynn!

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR
dialogues.text: Sports a new cowboy hat, leans on the bar, studying the audience as Loretta steps uncertainly to the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA SINGING 67
dialogues.text: She sings "There He Goes," awkwardly at first, not daring look at the audience, When she finally does, she sees the listening, looking up at her with enjoyment. She takes he relaxes a little, begins to enjoy it. We see her in the p cess of realizing the possibilities of a new life as a performer; a warmth flows from the audience that fills he and in turn flows back to them. As the song goes on, she looks at some of them: young couples dancing, older peopl listening with a smile, rowdy cowboys with bottles in the hands grinning up at her, and at the bar, alone, a middle woman crying to herself, drunk. Loretta’s eyes linger a moment on her. When the song ends, Doo is at the edge of the bandstand. applause is warm and genuine. She goes to Doo, a little dazed.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: They like me, Doo....

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: They gonna like you a whole lot more 'fore I'm finished. Go on, do another one. She starts back to the mike, is stopped by the Drunk Woma from the bar, mascara streaking down her face.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK WOMAN
dialogues.text: Bu'ful, honey...jus' bu'ful...you sang th' story my” life.... Loretta smiles uncertainly and continues to the mike, loo back at the woman staggering off into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta on her hands and knees setting out tomato plants hand. Nearby the youngest child sleeps on a blanket with

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 68
dialogues.text: old umbrella propped up. Loretta grubs in the dirt, unint gibly talking-singing to herself; mumbling, frowning tryi make up a song about the woman at the bar: We hear the wo “Honky Tonk Girl." She sets another tomato plant, somethi seems to click, she sits back on the dirt, smiles happily says to the baby:

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I wrote me a song...I wrote me a song -- your mama is a doggone songwriter, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo driving, Loretta feeding cookies, etc., to kids in ba

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: {holding forth) Thing is, you can sing in ever little honky-tonk in the country -- there's thousands doin' it ain't gettin’ nowhere and never will. What gives you the edge is gettin' yourself a record. And the next step is even more important -- that's gettin’ people to play the thing. But right now the thing to worry about is for you to make the best doggone record you can -- it all depends on that.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (admiringly) Boy, Doo, I sure didn't know you knew this much about the music business.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I don't. I'm just figurin' it out as I go. 70 OMITTED thru 72

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluttered, dingy. The kids wander around with bottles of Coke and baloney sandwiches. Loretta is on the floor with

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 73
dialogues.text: two duck-tailed sidemen (lead and bass) who look as if th rather be somewhere else. She's scared to death. Doo is behind the control panel with Speedy West who runs the st

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDY
dialogues.text: What you gonna sing for us, honey?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: She's gonna do this song she wrote herself, ‘Honky Tonk Girl.'

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. What key's that in, honey? Loretta looks helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all just play and she'll follow you all right.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDY
dialogues.text: She does talk, don't she, partner? Usually, if you can sing, you can talk, too.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: She can talk up a storm when she wants to. (to kids) Y'all keep out of the way now -- ' find a place to sit. Speedy and the sidemen exchange glances: They've seen , everything.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA AND SIDEMEN 74
dialogues.text: She nervously shows them chords. Doo comes up.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: , (aside, nervously) I don't think these boys like me, Doo. They ain't very friendly.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Forget about ‘em. Just sing. She nods. Speedy cues them and they begin. She misses her o cue and everything stops. She looks wretched, trembling

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 74
dialogues.text: Speedy calls for take two but Doo motions him to wait. He turns Loretta away from the sidemen, facing the kids who in chairs at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Sing to them, baby. Just like you was home. Second take begins. Loretta is more relaxed but the sidem sound awful. Doo is angry, but helpless. After a moment, Speedy hits the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDY
dialogues.text: {on intercom) Hey, people? Tell you what. Let's hold it for a while and lemme see if I can find a few more pickers.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Man, I spent ever last penny I had -- I can't afford no more pickers! And as bad as them two are, what do you want more for?

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDY
dialogues.text: (covers intercom) I mean more better, pardner. (beat; smiles) That little gal sings her hind end off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A professional five-piece band backs up Loretta as she si “Honky Tonk Girl" to the kids, never taking her eyes off Everybody else is smiling, knowing it's good. Doo is so h he can't keep still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo staggers in under the load of heavy cardboard boxes. Sets them on the living room floor where already a dozen boxes are stacked. One of them is open and Loretta is removing the contents; freshly pressed 45 singles of "Hon Tonk Girl." She puts one on the record player, listens, “ shaking her head, unable to believe it's actually her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo tacks up a chenille bedspread on the wall. He brings

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 77 in a floor lamp, removes the shade for use as a photograp light. He goes out and returns with an old graphlex on tripod. Meanwhile Loretta is in her slip painstakingly sequins and stars on a plain black dress. The kids are scattered around -- the boys running through the-house, girls, Betty Sue and Cissy watching Loretta sew.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Get your dress on. I gotta take this picture and get to work.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I ain't got all these doodads sewed on yet.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: It's just gonna be your head and shoulders, Stand over there in front of that backdrop.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You mean this bedspread? Wait a minute -- I orta put on some lip- stick or somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You look better natural. Don't you ever put no makeup.on your face. I don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY SUE
dialogues.text: Mama. ..?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Just a minute, darlin'. Let me finish this up -- Smile, now. She does; he snaps the picture.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I gotta go. Where's my lunch bucket? a sewing the Lightly kisses her, hugs Betty Sue and Cissy and hurries Loretta resumes sewing sequins.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY SUE
dialogues.text: Are you and Daddy goin' out again tonight. Mama?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Yeah, honey, I'm a-singin' over in Lynden.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY SUE
dialogues.text: Can I go with you?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: It's this rough ol' honky-tonk, honey. You can't be goin’ there. From the living room comes the sound of the record: Doo p it on as he was leaving. .

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Hear that? That's Mommie's record. Betty Sue sulks unhappily. Loretta continues sewing as th record plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo on his D-4 moving up a steep grade. Beside him is a c of Cash Box magazine, with a comprehensive list of every try DJ in America, complete with addresses. He folds the over and concentrates on his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo, bleary-eyed, yawning, pecks at an old typewriter. Th Cash Box list of DJ's is tacked to the wall in front of h He types: "Dear Mr. DJ. Here is the new big hit from Zero recording star Loretta Lynn..." He places the letter, a record, and the photo he took of Loretta in front of the spread into an envelope, addresses it, and marks another off the list -- three’ quarters of them are marked throug He looks at’ the’clock -- 61330°A.M.° Stretches, gets his bucket and hat and starts out. Loretta enters in her nigh gown.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (worried) You work all night again, honey...?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I'll grab me a nap later on. Gotta go, baby ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doo...all this leavin' the kids so much, and you spendin' all your

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: kt

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 78-B
dialogues.text: LORETTA (Cont'd) money and workin’ so hard... well, it's kind of scarin' me....

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Can't be scared if you want to make anything out of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I thought I had made somethin' out of myself, Doo. A wife for you, as mother to them kids. We ain't never thought this through, Doo.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (putting arm around her} Look, baby. We're started on it, now. Let's see it through. If it don't work out, we'll still have all this. I gotta go now. He scoops up the envelopes and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (smiles slightly) Who knows? Maybe we'll get lucky.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You make your own luck in this life, good, bad, or indifferent. Be ready when I get home. We gotta drive all the way to Spokane. He goes. Loretta looks at the photo of herself, smiles. F better. Doo's car drives away outside. Seeing his coffee cup, she turns it upside down in the saucer and "reads" t grounds. She hears someone faintly calling her name as if from a long distance. She goes to the backdoor and looks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Misty, wet fields. She listens, hears nothing, steps out the cool air, shivering in the nightgown. She sees a figu in the mist at the edge of the field. She looks at him cl The figure turns.... It's Ted. He wears his mining clothes, his face and hands grimed with coal dust. He smiles sadly at her. A voice shouts through the mist, from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mw

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Loretta. Starts toward Ted, but he disappears in the mist. She sta petrified, frightened. The voice calls her name again, an suddenly a figure moves out of the mist -- her Neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Loretta? Long distance, Loretta. Your mother calling, from Kentucky. Emergency, she says. She gasps, knowing instantly what it is. She runs barefoo into the mist, across the field, sobbing....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candles at head and foot of coffin; Ted "prepared" by an undertaker's art. Several friends, relatives, move in and out of the house: there is food, drink, etc. -- a wake. Clara and Loretta stand looking at the body.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: He come to me, Mommie...when he died. I saw him...just as plain....

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: He wanted to be with you so much. You and them grandkids....

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Oh, Mommie, I shouldn't have gone away -- I should've been here. This is my home, Mommie.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: I'm gonna have to leave here too, Loretty. Can't keep this place up by myself. I'm gonna move up north, me and the young'uns. Get me a job.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I won't have no place to come home to...Who's gonna look after Daddy? She cries into Clara's shoulder. EXT. FRONT PORCH AND YARD - NIGHT sa Shadowy figures scattered around, the glowing of cigarett

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 80
dialogues.text: subdued conversation. In the yard, a group of men pass 4 bottle around, including Doc Turner, Red Lynn, Doolittle.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Ted had the black lung, and them nervous headaches of his, but the plain fact is he just worked hisself to death. It's a mystery to me how men can work so hard, and still not get nowhere. Doo listens, drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta comes out to the porch railing. Her uncle, Corman Webb, a shy mountain man comes up.

dialogues.speaker: CORMAN
dialogues.text: Loretta, your man was a-tellin' me you're one of them singers now. Ted always used to say what he missed most was you a-singin' to them babies. Lord, you could hear “you all over this holler.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: (coming out) Sing somethin’ now, honey...for us. Loretta chokes, tries to gather herself, and begins "Prec Memories." All listen, spellbound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men passing the bottle around.

dialogues.speaker: RED LYNN
dialogues.text: Gacdamn, if that ain't the prettiest thing I ever heard. You reckon ol' Ted can hear it somewheres?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: He never got over me takin' her away fror: home....

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You done the right thing, Doo, leavin' here. Anyhow, over and done now, I reckon.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Naw, it ain't, Doc. It ain't never gonna be over. He looks at Loretta singing, tears in her eye filling the night. EXT, GRAVEYARD - TED'S GRAVE - MORNING — LORE’ She kneels at the grave, placing some yellow In the b.g. a bulldozer is working noisily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He expertly makes a road from the graveyard di wooded trail. He stops, gets off and goes toward ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta kneeling at the grave as Doo comes up her.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I finished widenin' that trail. Next time it won't be so hard to get up here. She says nothing. He idly fingers the yellow plastic.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: All these real flowers growin' around here, why'd you get these plastic ones?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Because they don't die! The real ones just die, like everything else

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Honey....

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Daddy's gone, Momnie's moving away -- I ain't gonna have no home left

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (reaches for her) We got our home, honey ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Get away from me! Leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: s, her voice

dialogues.speaker: TTA 62
dialogues.text: flowers on it.

dialogues.speaker: ZER 83
dialogues.text: lown the steep,

dialogues.speaker: S3-A
dialogues.text: , hunkers beside flowers. They're

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: kt

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 83-A
dialogues.text: Stung, Doolittle pulls back. He walks back to the bulldoz hurt and angry. She cries at the grave a moment. Then com to him. He helps her onto the bulldozer and starts it off the trail.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (over the engine) Listen. We gotta decide somethin' now. All them pictures and records I sent to them radio stations -- most of ‘em are right here in this part of the country. If we're really gonna do this thing, we gotta go see ‘em -- in person -- make sure they play that record! I already talked to your mama -- she said she'd take care of the kids: But we gotta move now -- understand? She says nothing; turns away.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: All right. JI ain't gonna push you into nothin'. It's your choice. If you don't want it, we'll just go back to what we was doin‘, that's all.... She slowly looks at him as he steers the tractor down the

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (softly) I want it, Doo....

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Can't hear you.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I want it -- I want to be a singer! I want it real bad, Doo?! Doo says nothing; just nods and steers the bulldozer....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo and Loretta getting into the car; the kids crying and clinging to them. They pull away; the kids all clinging t Clara now. Loretta looks back waving as long as she can.. until the car disappears down the trail away from Butcher Holler.  ps 86 87 88

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car speeds along; the Radio is being tuned, stations skipping by, static, etc., until:

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
