dialogues.text: «..your voice of country music in the tri-state area. And now here's that big number one hit by Miss Patsy Cline, 'Walkin' After Midnight.' Loretta leans in and turns it up. Doo checks the Cash Box list of stations and DJ's taped to his sun visor.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: All right. Station WCBL. DJ's named Bobby Day. Keep your eyes open for the transmitter.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: The what? Doo gives her a look. ANGLE - STATION TRANSMITTER -— DAY 87 looming over the landscape, a small station at the foot.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: drives the car into the parking lot. Loretta's in the bac in panties and bra hurriedly trying to pull on her dress the sewed-on sequins and a pair of white boots.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doggone it, Doo, wait -- people can look in here and see me!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hurry up, then -- we're there.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I don't know what to do once we get in there -- what am I supposed to say?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Don't even think about it -- just talk. He parks; she frantically tries to pull her boots on.  ps 89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small operation; nobody there except the DJ, Bobby Day, e a sandwich at his microphone while a record plays and an engineer in a control booth. He is startled to see Lorett in her dress and Doo in his white hat stroll into the stu

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Uh -- hey -- sorry, folks -- no visitors in the studio ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (gamely) Uh, hi, Bobby! Uh, my name is Loretta Lynn. And. Uh. I sent you a picture and my brand new record on the Zero label. And.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (hastily) What? Look, folks, no kiddin', you can't be here while I'm doin' a show -- okay? Engineer signals “stand by" -- record is ending.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (sweating) It's a song I wrote myself called ‘Honky Tonk Girl'. I got the idea from ---

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (thinking fast) Yeah, right -- I got it and played it. Just sort of laid there -- now thanks for comin' in y'all -- (on the air; signals Doo and Loretta to be quiet) You're listenin' to tri-state country with your Deejay, Bobby Day right here til six o'clock, neighbors -~ and now, here's a word from our good friends down at Hutchen's Hot Pig. A recorded commercial begins. During the above Loretta ha spotted her record -- unwrapped, in a stack of others. Di traught, she waves it at Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You played it, huh? You ain't even took it outta the wrapper!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (as commercial continues) Look, you know how many do-it- yourself records I get ever day? If I played them all I wouldn't have time to play anything else ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: But why'd you lie to us? Why'd you say people didn't like us? Doolittle worked so hard to get us that record and --- She cries loudly.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (frantically) Hey, shut her up, willya? I'm goin' back on the air ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (nonchalantly) Ain't nothin’ I can do, pardner. Once she gets wound up.... "On the Air" sign comes on; only one thing for Bobby to d

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (shielding mike from her sobs) Folks, we got a special treat for you here today -- a young lady who I predict is gonna go all the way --~ Loretta stops crying and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Tell the friends and neighbors all about yourself, darlin’. He thrusts the mike in her face; she panics, goes totally Looks around desperately for Doo -- just in time to see h bolting out the front door. She looks back at Bobby and t to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bursts out the front door, dives into the car and turns o radio, nervously waiting for it to fade in; finally ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (on radio, sound- ing very at home) -- and then I sung it for Doolittle -- that's my husband -- but every- one else calls him Mooney on account of he used to sell moonshine back in Butcher Holler ---

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (laughing) Where?

dialogues.speaker: CAR AND INTERVIEW
dialogues.text: can't believe it; she sounds like a pro.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Butcher Holler -- that's where me and Doo is from back in Kentucky -- anyway I wrote this song and Doo said that's about as good a song as I ever heard, good as Patsy Cline, and I said, aw, ain't nobody good as Patsy.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Well, folks, let's give it a listen -~- brand new, on the Zero label, Miss Lorene Lynn singing ‘Honky Tonk Girl' ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (as record starts) Loretta. Loretta Lynn. Not Lorene. In the car, Doo laughs out loud.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: Both laugh, happy -- Loretta peeling off baloney slices, sandwiches for them both.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You sure got over bein' bashful fast.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I done what you said -- just opened my mouth and out it come. I couldn*t stop -- and I didn't have no more notion of what I was gonna Say than a rabbit!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: kt o~ 92

dialogues.speaker: 95-A
dialogues.text: oo

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Well, you just keep on bein' a rabbit, then.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Where's the next one -- want me to watch out for that transmitter?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Yeah -- watch out for that trans— mitter. They speed on down the highway.

Lonely transmitters against the sky; the car speeding dow two-lane country highways; highline poles; the call-lette signs of small country radio stations; and close shots of the car radio as the dial skips across it. We hear snatch of widely-ranging music: Pat Boone "Love Letters in the S Ray Charles, "What'd I Say?", Kingston Trio "Tom Dooley", Peter, Paul and Mary "Blowin' in the Wind", Buddy Holly " Fade Away" and finally, loud and clear, Loretta's record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up to the pumps in front of the store. They get out and go inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT, SMALL GROCERY
dialogues.text: A radio is playing behind the counter: Lefty Frizell's "Please Release Me." Doo points to a roll of baloney in the freezer and a fat, old woman starts slicing it. Loret wanders around looking at a display of candy and toys.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doo, can we send the kids some suckers or somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: We ain't got a cent to spare, baby. Loretta nods, resigned, watches as the old woman wraps th baloney in paper.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I sure am gettin’ sick of eatin' baloney.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: kw

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You know what they say about baloney, don't you? Makes you horny.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Are you so ignorant you don't know what horny means?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: No, What's it mean? Laughing loudly, he pays for the baloney and goes out the door. Loretta follows, imploring.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Come on, Doo -= what's it mean?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Just fix me a baioney sandwich, will ya, baby? Through the screen door we watch them get into the car an drive off. The radio behind the counter is still playing:

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: Here's a brand-new record by a brand new artist that's startin' to catch on with all you country music fans -- Loretta Lynn singin’ "Honky-Tonk Girl", The fat woman listens, idly beating time as she reads her newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car whips down another highway; radio skips over the again, more music of the era. The highway seems empty and endless....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pan down it as "Honky Tonk Girl" plays. The car pull into the parking lot and Loretta gets out in her cowgirl outfit, looking eager. Doo stays in the car, sleepily tur on the radio.  kw 98

dialogues.speaker: DOO IN CAR
dialogues.text: A kindly Dd named Hugh Cherry interviews Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH
dialogues.text: With all these months of bein' on the road, have you hit Nashville yet?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: No, sir, but I'm a-dyin' to. I'm gonna get on the Grand Ole Opry,’. too, soon as I can.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH
dialogues.text: Well, sometimes you have to pay a lotta dues to get on the Opry.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Pay dues?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH
dialogues.text: For most people it takes years and years of hard work. Still, from the looks of thing -- {reaches for a copy of Cash Box) -- you're off to a real good start ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (oblivious) You reckon? Shoot, we been drivin’ so much I don't even know where I am half the time -- oh, it's fun, we just talk and sing and Doo, that's my husband, he'll.get to actin' horny ---

dialogues.speaker: INT, CAR
dialogues.text: Doo's head jerks up.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH
dialogues.text: (startled) What -- ?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (oblivious) And the more I laugh the hornier he gets --- The station goes dead. Doo slides down in the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An irate Station Manager storms around at Loretta as Doo and Hugh Cherry look on. fanmreinn  kw 99

dialogues.speaker: STATION MANAGER
dialogues.text: I don't know where you think you are, lady, but that kind of smut don't go in this part of the country.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I didn't know it was dirty: I thought horny just meant cuttin’ up and actin' sillv --

dialogues.speaker: STATION MANAGER
dialogues.text: Come off the dumb hillbilly act, lady.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Mister, if you knew Loretta, you'd know that ain't no act.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (staunchily) Thank you, Doo.

dialogues.speaker: STATION MANAGER
dialogues.text: I'll be damned lucky if the FCC don't lift my license for this. I can you one thing: I'll never play any record of yours on this station! He slams out. Loretta is miserable.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Dad-dammit, Loretta -- don't you ever stop to think what you're sayin?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You told me not to! And stop a-growlin' at me?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH
dialogues.text: Don't worry about him, Kids. If you're on the charts, you'll get played all right. ©

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What charts?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH
dialogues.text: You got a hit -~ don't you know that? (sees their confusion) That really isn't an act, is it?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HUGH (Cont'd) Look here -- Cash Box magazine came out today, “Honky-Tonk Girl" by Loretta Lynn. You really didn't know? You're number fourteen, nationwide.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Hell, mister, we're new at this.... He looks at Loretta; she looks at him, then both burst ou laughing and hugging each other. The Station Manager glow suspiciously through the window....

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 100
dialogues.text: Doo drives along at a rapid clip, a little smile keeps pl around his lips, he hums along with a staticky song on th radio. We assume Loretta is asleep in the backseat. Then head appears behind Doo's. She begins to nuzzle him, run hands through his hair, onto his chest. Doo gets more and more distracted.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I love you, Doo.... His eyes cut back and forth, desperately searching for an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is parked in the shadows. The rest area is desert semi's whine down the interstate nearby. After a moment, gets out of the backseat, looking very contented. Loretta sits up, they look at each other. Smile. Doo drives on as she lies down to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is asleep. Silence. She stirs, awakens. Looks in the front seat -- no Doolittle. A little alarmed, she sits up Looks out the window and discovers they are parked on a c street. She looks around and sees something that makes her gasp ---  al #02119 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fhe ancient crumbling Ryman Auditorium. In the rising sun it seems infused with a golden glow...She gets out of the car. The streets are deserted, quiet. She stands in the middle of the street gazing at the old building in awe. Doo comes around the corner with a bag of coffee and doug nuts. Seeing her awestruck expression, he grins.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: That o1' buildin’ would sure hold a lotta hay, wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: That's the Grand Ole Opry, Doo!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You want chocolate or glazed?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: The Grand Ole Opry... (suddenly frightened) Doo. What if they won't let me in there?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: They better let us in. I just spent our last livin' cent on these dough- nuts. (pause) Besides, how they gonna keep us out? We're number fourteen. (beat) Nationwide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge crowd roars, whoops, whistles; Grand Ole Opry Satu Night. On stage, an announcer, Grant Turner, introduces:

dialogues.speaker: TURNER
dialogues.text: And now, the Grand Ole Opry presents the Pet Milk Show, with Ernest Tubb and his Texas Troubadours!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 104
dialogues.text: The crowd goes wild as Ernest sings "Walkin' the Floor Ov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of people milling around, spilling onstage as the goes on -- friends, relatives, hangers-on, sidemen, and s

dialogues.speaker: HANK SNOW, ROY ACUFF, MINNIE PEARL, BILL MONROE, LESTER
dialogues.text: FLATT, etc. In the midst of this glamour are Doo, hiding his nervousn and Loretta in her homemade dress, looking lost and terri A nervous little Stage Manager {who stutters) is calling etta's name repeatedly, but it can't be heard over the di Finally she hears it -- her head jerks up in fright -- an she hurries nervously to the little man.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: You Loretta Lynn? I been a-callin' and a-callin' and -- now Mr. Devine said to put you on Ernest's show; now you you go stand right yonder and keep your eyes on Ernest, and he'll introduce you. If the show ain't runnin" too long. He moves off quickly to find somebody else. Loretta, flus goes to the wings and waits, very frightened, uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'm scared, Doo -- scared I don't belong here. :

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You belong here as much as anybody -- stop complainin' and relax.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Nine months ago I hadn't never sung for nobody ‘cept you and the kids -- I ain't ready, Doo. I ain't paid my dues to be here!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Then by God, we'll pay ‘em later on. He starts off.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Where you goin' -~ !

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: If there's one thing I can't stand, it's a nervous damn woman, I'm gonna get me some air. She's left alone, terrified. Looks out at Ernest Tubb, ho he'll never call her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo comes out the stage door and lights a cigarette -- hi hands are shaking wildly. In front of him is the rear ent to Tootsie's Orchid Lounge -- he sees some musicians comi of it. He hurries inside,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed with musicians and singers. Pushing up to the bar, jostles against a sexy redhead who smiles at him drunkenl

dialogues.speaker: REDHEAD
dialogues.text: What's your hurry, cowboy?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I'm tryin' to get me a quick beer and get back to the Opry ---

dialogues.speaker: REDHEAD
dialogues.text: Well, you can't be shy -- Hey, Tootsie! Wait on this cowboy -- he's ina hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onstage, Ernest Tubb finishes a number.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST TUBB
dialogues.text: Thank you, neighbors. Folks, right now I want y'all to meet a little gal I think you're gonna like a whole lot -- let's make her feel real welcome now... Miss Loretta Lynn! Applause: Tubb turns to her: she freezes. Grant Turner gi her a little shove and she's onstage and singing, growing and more relaxed and confident as the audience responds.  al 109 110

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo still hasn't got his beer, and the Redhead is getting friendler. Behind the bar a radio is tuned to the Opry bu it can barely be heard above the noise.

dialogues.speaker: REDHEAD
dialogues.text: Well, if you ain't a picker, what are you?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: My wife's singin' on the Opry. I better forget about that drink ---

dialogues.speaker: REDHEAD
dialogues.text: Oh, I see -= you're one of the husbands. Well, I'm one of the wives, darlin'. How 'bout one fifth wheel buyin' another one a drink?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (suddenly hears radio) That's her -- she's on right now! Goddammit!

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA PERFORMING
dialogues.text: Doo starts back, knows he'll never get there in time; lea over bar and tries to hear the radio. A large man -- Cowb comes by and puts his arm around Redhead.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: H'o, sweet thang -- where's that big ugly husband of yours? .

dialogues.speaker: REDHEAD
dialogues.text: Out in the parkin' lot tryin' to get sober enough to do his show.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (as they laugh loudly) Hey, y'all -- I'm tryin' to hear the radio ---

dialogues.speaker: REDHEAD
dialogues.text: He's got a wife singin' on the Opry.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: That right? Hell, you got it made, man. Just lay back and count it as the ol' lady rakes it in.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: al
on

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: {getting mad) I do my share of the work, mister.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Sure you do, hoss.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I told you politely. I'm tryin' to hear the radio.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: That's your job, huh? She sings and you listen. Doo whirls and socks Cowboy across the room. In the sudde quiet, Doo hears Loretta finishing her song -- just as Co recovers and leaps on Doo with a smash to the jaw. INT. OPRY STAGE - NIGHT lll Loretta blinks happily as the applause continues.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST TUBB
dialogues.text: Miss Loretta Lynn, neighbors -- Loretta, how'd you like to come back and see us again next week?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Next week...? We-l...shoot, Mr. Tubb. I sure ain't got nothin’ else a-goin? g' Audience laughs and applauds; Ernest does his closing the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People throng around her, congratulating her, as she look around desperately for Doo. Finally, she spots him at the stage door hastling with the police guard who won't let h back it. She runs for him ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes flying out the door and into his arms -- not no ing his jaw beginning to swell.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Did you hear ‘em, honey? Did you hear ‘em? They liked me!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: kt o~ 113

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I heard ‘em baby ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: They asked me to come back next week! It's like a dream, Doo!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What we gotta do now is set down and plan real careful what to do next.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'm too happy to even think about that now! I don't care if I die = right now, Doo -~ if I never sing another song -- it just ain't never gonna get no better than this! (sees his jaw) You hurt yourself, honey? Your jaw's swellin' up ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Just from grinnin', baby. Just from pure happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta's voice on loudspeakers to dozens of fans cluster around the record shop door. Fans passing in cars blow th horns and shout, etc. She sings, "I Fall to Pieces."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live radio broadcast ("Midnight Jamboree"); fans jammed i among record shelves, etc. After the first verse of "I Fa to Pieces" Loretta says:

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Friends, this song is the number: one hit by Patsy Cline, and I want to dedicate it to her, cause I guess y'all heard she's over here in the hospital ‘cause she was in a car wreck. Patsy, if you're listenin’ this song is for you. . Sings the last verse. In the audience is Doolittle, two children asleep in his arms, the other two drowsily hangi onto him. He listens, pleased, as she sings.  kt 116

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show’s over: Loretta and Ernest Tubb sign autographs. Doo pulls the car up and double-parks. The kids are sleeping. shiny new Cadillac suddenly double-parks in front of him aman jumps out. Doo sees him go up to Loretta, take her a and pull her aside, whispering in her ear. Doo growls, th open the door and heads for the man.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Doo -- listen here to this: Patsy Cline heard me sing her song tonight! She's a-wantin' to meet me -- right now!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (offers hand to Doo who is still suspicious) I'm Charlie Dick. Patsy's husband.

dialogues.speaker: . LORETTA
dialogues.text: Boy, I'd give near anything to meet Patsy Cline -- _ (pleading look at Doo) But I reckon we gotta get them young ‘uns home....?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (beat) I'll get the kids home. If Patsy Cline wants to meet you, then you go on and meet her. You can't pass up somethin' like this. She happily kisses Doo and gets in Charlie's car and they drive away. Doo gets in his car and takes the kids home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, with something tucked under his coat, leads Lore down the corridor toward a room. From the room comes loud laughter -- and two nurses come out laughing and shaking heads as they pass Loretta. Loretta, excited and thrilled any fan, goes tentatively into ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta draws back, shocked; in bed is a woman with her f bruised and bandaged, her eyes black -- Patsy Cline.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: “~~ kt

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Charlie -- you get me beer like I told you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Right here, Patsy. Pulls a six pack from under his coat; opens one. Patsy gr for a hospital straw on her bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (to Loretta) Hand me that straw, willya, honey? Loretta does and Patsy puts in the can and drinks the bee Charlie kisses Patsy lightly winks at Loretta and exits. Loretta stands staring, speechless, at Patsy drinking the beer through the straw.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (after a moment) What's the matter? Ain't you never seen no glamourous star before? (beat) Want a beer?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Are...are you really Patsy Cline....?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Are you really Loretta Lynn? (Loretta smiles, relaxes a little) You're stirrin' things up around this town, you know that? How many times you sung on the Opry now?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (proudly) I been on seventeen straight times.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Lotta gals been here a lot longer'n you ain't gettin’ on near that much. (beat) They're askin' who you been sleepin’ with to get on so much.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (shocked) I ain’t sleepin' with nobody to get nothin’ -- that's the dirtiest doggone lie -- who's a-sayin' that?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: o~ kt

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Gals that are sleepin' with everybody and still ain't gettin’ nowhere. Whoo -- you got a temper big as your voice, ain't you? That's good -- they both come in handy in this business.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (suddenly) I just can't believe I'm a-standin' here talkin' to Patsy Cline! Oh, Patsy, sO many good things are a- happenin' so fast to me and Doolittle -- he's my husband only most people calls him Mooney -- and now, meetin' you -- Patsy, you ain't mad at me for doin' your song tonight, are you?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (softly) Mad? If anything, I'm scared -- you done it so good, I... (stops; has tears in her eyes) Well. Most people wouldn't've thought of singin' to me like that. {wipes her eyes) Listen: when I get outta here me and you gonna go out together and raise some hell -~ okay? Us country gals orta stick together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fully recovered -- very glamourous, smiling, very much a sweeps on stage to loud applause and sings "Back in’Baby' Arms." In the wings, Loretta stands watching, unconsciously imit Patsy's movenents. Patsy turns and smiles at her, Loretta smiles back happily. Song continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noisy, smoky, crowded with musicians and singers. Patsy bursts in the backdoor with Loretta, waves at acquaintanc and heads for a booth where Charlie and Doolittle are dri pouring bourbon into "set-ups" under the table.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mw 118

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: What've y'all two devils been doin' besides gettin' in trouble -- don't tell me. Hey, Tootsie -- bring us two co-colas!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Patsy, Mooney says he's gonna take me squirrel huntin'.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (trying Charlie's drink) Don't you bring home no squirrels, Charlie Dick. When I left Virginia I swore I'd never eat another damn squirrel long as I lived.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Boy, I love squirrel meat. Don't you like squirrels, Patsy?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Reckon I must. I married Charlie. Charlie laughs loudly; Patsy hugs him affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Charlie knows I love him -- but I have to remind him ever now and then he ain't nothin’ but a damn tax deduction.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (picking it up) Yeah, Doolittle Lynn, that goes for you, too. And don't you forget it! Doo doesn't laugh. His eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: small, modest house. Doo on phone setting up an appointme for Loretta; she making sandwiches for the kids. Through window she sees Patsy's Cadillac roar into the driveway. gets out waving and bursts into the house.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Little gal -- you and Mooney are comin' on the road with me. How soon can you get ready?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mw

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: The road...?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: We can't do it, Patsy. We got meetin's, record dates ~~~

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: They'll be here when you get back. You can't be a country singer without you go on the road -~ now you gotta go, it's all set.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: We could get my brother to set with the kids -- aw, Doo, can't we go?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Is Charlie goin'?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Charlie don't like the road. Besides, he's got a day job.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doggone it, I'm a-goin'. How about it, Doo. You comin', too? He looks at her levelly, then nods. Patsy throws her arms around Loretta. Doo goes into the kitchen where the kids eating, watching curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old model bus speeds down the highway. Int. BUS - DAY 120 Patsy and Lorraine ride together, looking at sights along way, laughing. Doo stares out the window nearby. Patsy's band is also aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulis in behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is packed as Patsy finishes "Walkin' After Midn

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 121
dialogues.text: Doo and Loretta are in the crowd near the stage. Deo is drinking. Slick Cowboy Number Two comes up to Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: SLICK NUMBER TWO
dialogues.text: Hey, honey, how ‘bout dancin" one?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (motions to Doo) Ask my husband. Slick moves off.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: If you don't get me a weddin' ring soon I swear I'm gonna buy my own self one.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I'll get you a weddin' ring, don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: When? Our Golden Weddin' day? Patsy is introducing her (ad lib) and she goes on stage.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: This here's a song I wrote about my husband. That's him standin' right over there, boys, with that mean, jealous look. She sings "Don't Come Home A-Drinkin" (With Lovin' On You Mind.) Doo at bar orders drink from the Bartender.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: That's your wife up yonder, ain't it? (Doo nods) She makes it and you spend it, huh? Boy, you got it made. Doo tenses, considers bashing his face in; doesn't. Turns back and watches Loretta, growling, drinking.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 122
dialogues.text: Doo's asleep. Loretta is a few seats away, a flashlight propped as she writes a song. Patsy wanders up, Loretta s

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Don't stop -- I'm just wanderin', can't sleep....

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: It wasn't comin', anyway.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: A new song? That's a gift. I wish I had, bein' able to write. How do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I just watch to see what me and Doolittle is gonna do, and write it down.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: {shows a piece of paper) Here's a new one they sent me. See what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patsy sings a few bars of "Sweet Dreams of You."

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Mm. That's pretty.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Ain't it? First time I heard it I thought I was gonna cream my jeans.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What's that mean? Patsy looks at her, then leans over and whispers in her Loretta looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Aw, women can't do that. (beat) Can they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ear. The bus is pulling in behind the outdoor stage where a cr is running sound checks. 122 123 and 124 125  mw 126 127

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A curtain strung over the bus' backseats makes a dressing room. Mirrors propped on seats, etc. Patsy and Loretta ar dressing. Sounds of show in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Don't you ever wear no makeup?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doo don't like it. He likes me natural.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Ain't nothin' more natural than” Makeup. Here. Tosses Loretta some lipstick, eye liner, powder which Lor happily puts on with the air of doing something forbidden

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (getting up) I'm gonna bring you on right after my first song, so be ready. Loretta nods; Patsy goes. Loretta continues making up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: deserted except for Doo, slumped in a seat, sipping from bottle. Patsy heard singing in the b.g. Loretta comes out the back heading for the door, Seeing Doo, she is startle

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You scared me. What're you doin' sittin' there like that?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (peers at her) What you got on your face...?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I just thought I'd try it -- you like it?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You know I don't like it -- get it off.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I said get it off ---

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 127
dialogues.text: He lurches out of his seat for her but she quickly runs o the bus toward the stage. Doo stands glowering angrily in dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta enters to applause and she and Patsy begin "Sweet Dreams of You."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intercut with above. As the girls sing in close harmony Doo wanders, resentful drinking. Near the stage a few cars are pulled up, includ a late model convertible with an attractive blonde sittin on the fender, watching the show. Doo looks interestedly her; she returns it....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show is over; crowds gone. Bus is running and loaded. Pat and Loretta walk toward it from the stage -- they've been signing autographs. Loretta suddenly sees the convertible with Doo and the Blonde kissing inside. The blonde is wea Doo's hat. Loretta's throat catches; her eyes blaze. She stalks furiously toward the car. The blonde looks up startled:

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Woman, if you wanna keep that arm you better get it offa my husband ---

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (defiantly) Who you tellin' what?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'm just about to stop tellin' and start hittin' ---

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Well, let me tell you somethin! -- if you was keepin' your man satis- fied he wouldn't have to go nowhere else! Loretta starts for her; but the Woman quickly back~pedals around the car. The bus horn honks in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (to Woman) I ain't got time to fool with you now. (to Doolittle) You come on, if you can walk -- they gonna leave without us.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: {they hurry for the bus) I can walk all right. What're you gettin’ in such an uproar about? I wasn't doin' nothin' anyway.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I saw you doin' nothin’ ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I got tired of standin' around by myself -- I need somebody to talk to ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: That didn't look like no talkin’ to me --- She gets on the bus; he follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others watch as they continue the fight.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'm warning you ~- I better not ever catch you with trash like that again ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Don't you warn me about nothin', woman -- you hear me? Not about nothin'! They realize everybody is watching them. They sit in separate seats, still furious. Patsy looks concerned. The bus pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo slumps, glowering, hung over. Loretta is angry too, scribbling furiously on a piece of paper. The rest of the bus watches them as if they were about to explode.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Doo? Listen here to this. (reads from paper) ‘Women like you are a dime a dozen you can find 'em anywhere. For you to move in I'd have to move over and I'm gonna stay right here. It'll be over my dead body so get out while you can. ‘Cause you ain't woman enough to take my man.‘ The others watch tensely as Doo growls, raises his bloods eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Where'n the hell you get the idea for them things, I'll never know. Loretta looks at him incredulously -- he grins. Then. she grins. He puts his arm around her as the others look on i amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Owen Bradley supervises a large professional recording se of "You Ain't Woman Enough." Doo and the kids watch proud from the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patsy's Cadillac pulls up to the curb in front of an expe women's store and she and Loretta get out, waving good-by Doo and Charlie in the car.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Y'all go somewhere and get in trouble -- me and Loretta gonna do some heavy spendin'! The car roars off and the women, dressed in western outfi and boots, go into ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An "Old Nashville" store, staid and snobbish. Loretta is little intimidated, but not Patsy.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: o~ nw 136

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She moves 82 136

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (to blue-haired Saleslady) Hey, honey? We need a major over- haul here -- I want you to turn this little heifer into a thorough- bred mare. Can you handle that?

dialogues.speaker: SALESLADY
dialogues.text: (stiffly) We'll need some measurements. I'11l get my tape. off.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Nashville's just full of people that wishes there wasn't any country people in country music.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You was talkin’ to her kind of smart.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I talk to her the way I talk to everybody. She's the kind talks different dependin' on how much money she's talkin’ to. (suddenly) Lord, look at that -- I gotta have me that! She rushes to a lingerie display and looks at a mannequin wearing a brief shortie nightgown -- bright red.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I gotta have one. You get one, too -- give ol' Mooney a charge.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I need to give him somethin', way he's been actin' lately. The Saleslady returns, all smiles now, with a smiling Man

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Miss Cline, it's a pleasure to welcome you to our store.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Thank you, darlin’. Listen -- I want you to fix this little gal up right -- top to bottom, inside and out, the works, okay? Oh -- and wrap up one of them red night- gowns for me. Red's the color

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PATSY (Cont'd) drives men wild -- you know that, honey?

dialogues.speaker: SALESLADY
dialogues.text: (graciously) It surely is, yes indeed. Just come with me, miss. She leads Loretta off to a fitting room as Patsy grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 136 137 In the Cadillac, Charlie dozes in the front seat. Doo see in the back with a bottle. Looks up and sees ---

dialogues.speaker: 137-A
dialogues.text: coming towards the car, Loretta looking beautiful and cit in a new dress, hairdo, ané@ makeup. She steps up to Doo proudly. He looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What do you think, Doo?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Get that junk off your face.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: No. I like it and it's a-stayin'.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: {getting threateningly out of the car) You know I don't like that stuff. You just testin' me -- is that it?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Hey, hold on a minute now -- look, Mooney, it was my idea, but just look at her -- she's beautiful ~--

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You don't have to explain nothin’ to him, Patsy. If I want to wear makeup I'll wear it ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You'll do what I tell you -- by God, I raised you the way I wanted you and you ain't gonna change now ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You can't boss me no more! I'll do like I want to -- you ain't my daddy!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mw

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 137-A
dialogues.text: Doo slaps her hard; she reels back, then goes at him with fists, feet, etc. They fight viciously as a crowd gathers -- recognizing her and Patsy, snapping away with cameras. Loretta swings her purse at his head -- Doo throws up his hand to block it -- and the purse hits his finger with an audible pop. He draws back, cursing, holding his finger.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Get in the car y'all -- hurry ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (worried as Doo clutches his finger) Is it broke, Doo? Maybe we orta find a doctor ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I'll find all the damn doctor I need myself! He stalks off across the parking lot. Patsy pulls Loretta looking regretfully at Doo -- into the car and they speed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta, makeup gone from her face, folds the new dress i a box, to return it. She is in pain -- a migraine headach She stops what she's doing, clutching her temples. Takes some aspirin. She hears a car in the driveway, looks out and sees --- .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi cab lets Doo out. He comes slowly to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes in, avoiding her eyes. His finger is bandaged.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: It's really busted, huh? He starts for the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Ain't you gonna talk, Doo? I know

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LORETTA (Cont'd) what happened today, it wasn't about me wearin' no makeup. Why don't you talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (slowly) I think what I'm gonna do...is get me a job somewhere. Truck drivin’, mechanicin', somethin' I'm good ate.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You're good at managin' me. I wouldn't be here if it wasn't for you.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Gettin' here's one thing. Bein' here's another. My job's done. So I'll just find me another'n.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: If this is gonna break us up then I'll quit, Doo. I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Successful people can't quit, baby. {sees her holding her head) Got another one of your headaches? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Just like your daddy. Coal dust give him his headaches. I guess I'm what gives ‘em to you... (takes something from his pocket) Figure it was about time. It's a wedding ring. She looks at it, starts to cry. They hold each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo works on a car on a rack, favoring his still-bandaged finger. Radio plays "You Ain't Woman Enough." He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modern, sunken room: Patsy's small son Randy rocks vigo ously on a hobby horse. Patsy sits embroidering a tablecl listening to a tape of herself singing "Crazy." A knock a the door: Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: you must be a mind reader: I was just gonna call you to come and listen to this new stuff I cut -- come on in. Patsy goes to start the tape again; doesn't notice Lorett worried expression.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (cueing the tape) I'm a little worried about maybe I'm gettin' too far away from country -- tell me what you think. {sees her mood) What's wrong, honey?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Patsy...I'm pregnant again....

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (pause) Randy...go play in the other room, darlin’... (he goes) I guess with four others, you're pretty sure....?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (néds) I don't wanna have it, Patsy. I been haven' babies since I was fourteen -- I'm gettin' to be a stranger to the ones I already got ---

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (holds her) Easy, little gal...there's ways of ...not havin' babies. Yours wouldn't be the first that come along at the wrong time. You under- stand, honey?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I ain't got no right not to want to have this baby. I'm just selfish, Patsy, just thinkin’ of me.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: What's Mooney think?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I think maybe he's thinkin' it'll get us back like we used to be.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LORETTA (Cont'd) (beat) I gotta get home to the kids. I didn't even get to hear your tape.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Plenty of time later for that -- hey, wait a minute. I got some stuff to give you. She gets a cardboard box full of clothes from the closet.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Somehow these doggone clothes has just hung here in the closet and shrunk. Includin' this. She holds up the red shortie nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (winks) Red'd the color drives ‘em wild, honey.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doo's wild enough all ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk to Loretta's car.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm doin’ a benefit over in Kansas City this weekend but when I get back, we'll go do some shoppin‘ for the baby -- okay?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Thanks, Patsy. For everything. She starts to get into the car.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Hey -- ain't you gonna hug me goodbye? Loretta puts the box down and embraces Patsy.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You're the only friend I got, Patsy.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Me and you, little gal, we're gonna stick together, no matter what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo and Loretta sleep, she's wearing the shortie nightgow The clock radio clicks on playing Patsy's "Sweet Dreams o you." Loretta comes awake, smiles sleepily, hearing Patsy Doo stirs.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: {as song ends) We'll continue our special memorial tribute to the late Patsy Cline in a moment. Patsy Cline, dead at 29, in a plane crash yesterday. Loretta stumbles out of bed to the phone, tremblingly tri to dial. Doo quickly comes after her.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What are you doin', baby ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: She can't be dead -- we was goin’ shoppin’ ~-- Doo gently takes the phone from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with Patsy's framed photograph on it, in the midst of doz of mourners; acres of flowers. Charlie Dick is dissolved grief. Loretta sits, isolate, in a folding chair, staring the coffin. Doo looks at her from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: DOO'S POINT OF VIEW 146
dialogues.text: He sees her look up suddenly as if spoken to. Her lips mo She smiles. Doo gets very frightened.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Doo drives them home down a dark Nashville street.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: One thing we gotta do is find us a bigger house for when the baby

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: kt 147

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Doo turns 89 147 DOOLITTLE (Cont'd) comes. You gotta think about how much time you're gonna take off.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get back to work soon's I can walk.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: All right.... the car down a dark street.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You gotta start makin' some pre- parations for your baby ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Your baby you mean.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What do you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You got me pregnant again so you can run me like you used to ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: That's a damn lie!

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: All my life it's been people runnin' me -- Daddy, then you -- Patsy told me I gotta run myself, like she did, she said --- She screams -- out of nowhere a train whistle blasts: Doo slams the breaks, skids -- as a freight train roars inches in front of them on a blind crossing. Both sit trembling as train rumbles past in front of the rain-smeared windshiel

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Patsy talked to me, she said we were gonna stick together, no matter what ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Stop that -- you listen to me! Patsy's dead and gone -- just like your Daddy's dead and gone: They can't talk to you, they can't do

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOOLITTLE (Cont'd) nothin' -- they're dead! I'm the one that's alive! I'm the one that's here! The train rattles past in the rain. Both calm themselves, look tentatively at each other....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nurse brings out a baby girl and hands it to Doo. He cradles it happily. Then another nurse comes out with ano baby girl and agives it to him. He stands, shocked, holdi the twins. A doctor comes out and looks at him -- Doo's f breaks into a large grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta in bed holds the two babies. Doo is nearby.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I got the names, Doo. Peggy and Patsy.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Which one's which?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (leoks at them, puzzles) I don't know. (beat) Reckon we'll just have to wait to see who grows up to be who.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: One thing's for sure. We can't put off no longer findin' us a bigger house somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: But right now, you gotta get some rest.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I ain't got time to get no rest. I'm goin' back to work, Doo, quick as I can. I'm started now, started real good, and I'm gonna keep a-goin'. I'm gonna work just as hard as I can as long as I can. So when I die, everybody's gonna know I been here....

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 149
dialogues.text: Doo listens, says nothing.

Camera reveals the extent of Hurricane Mills inside and o The ante-bellum mansion, the descending concrete steps wi Loretta's and Mooney's name inlaid; the mill house and po and inside, the stairwell lined with dozens of framed alb covers; walls lined with awards of all kinds. Mingled wit these images are shots of Loretta's modern bus roaring do a highway; then a large auditorium, a cheering crowd, her band, the Coal Miners, on stage in orange jumpsuits, an introduction: "Ladies and Gentlemen, the First Lady of Country Music, the only woman to win Entertainer of the Y one of the country's most admired women -- Miss Loretta L Loretta sweeps on stage, a full-blown star now, in her ch teristic long dress and long hair. She sings, enjoying he self. (Music over montage: "The Pill", "One's on the Way" and finally, Loretta performing "You're Lookin’ at Countr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show is over, seats are empty -- but hundreds of fans are lined up for autographs, passing before Loretta like pilg at a shrine, as she leans down to them from the edge of t stage. Fans buy pictures, albums, at tables set up nearby and hold them up to be autographed. Many fans are in whee chairs or elderly. Children are passed up to be photograp with her. There is genuine affection between her and the fans; she smiles and banters with each of them (ad lib) a the selling and packing up goes on around her.

dialogues.speaker: FANS
dialogues.text: (1) Loretta, next time you're here you gonna come and eat some catfish with us, you hear? (2) Will you hug my little girl while I take y'all's picture? I bet you miss your twins, don't you? (3) Old Man in Wheelchair: I had this stroke and 'bout. near died and I said. no. sir. I ain't a-fixin' to die 'til I get Loretty Lynn to give me a big ol' kiss?

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-
dialogues.text: Loretta, where's that husband of yours, that Mooney?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Honey, he stayed home and went a-huntin'. But I don't know what he’s a-huntin'.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND WOMAN
dialogues.text: I was readin' about him in one of them gossip papers -- drinkin’ and cheatin'. Why in the world do you put up with it?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Well, darlin', there wasn't but one man ever perfect in this world, and they crucified him. Thank the Lord, I don't ever have to worry about Doolittle gettin' crucified.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, HURRICANE MILLS
dialogues.text: A modern jeep roars up the driveway containing Doo and th twins -- now’six years’old. Jeep stops -- twins leap out run for the house, Doo chases them and.scoops them up und his arms and runs inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo kicks open the door, plops the twins down, turns on t bathtub as the girls start peeling off their dirty playcl Doo wears muddy farmclothes and caterpillar cap and is un

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Don't splash water all over the floor now -- Patsy, you scrub’ them feet good. You're dirty as a little pig.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: She looks like a pig, too.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Well, if I look like one then you do, too!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Your lama's comin' home soon. and ya'll gonna act like ladies instead of heatherns.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Aw, she'll just be sleepin' the whole times she’s here anway.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Hey, Daddy: -- can we have pork chops for supper? We want pork chops! They jump into the tub, splashing. Doo exits. INT. LIVING ROOM —- DAY 154 Doo goes to a large mantel which contains photos of the o children: Ernest Ray in warine's uniform; Betty Sue with husband; Jack and Cissy grown. From behind a photograph o himself and Loretta he fishes a pint of Old Charter and d Then goes toward kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta, exhausted, being led by Jim Webb, her driver, to the exit. Dozens of fans hurrying along beside her. A Sad-Faced woman stops her:

dialogues.speaker: SAD-FACED WOMAN
dialogues.text: Loretta, I wanted to tell you, when you sing...I feel like you're talkin’ about my life. I made this for you. Hands Loretta a doll made in her image. Loretta, touched, her.

dialogues.speaker: SAD-FACED WOMAN
dialogues.text: (solicitously) You look so tired. Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'm beat, honey. Feel like I been on the road forever. She smiles and turns to go when suddenly a pair of scisso flashes into her hair -- she screams. Jim Webb curses and hurries her out the door. A fan -- a-plump, gum-chewing woman -~ proudly displays a swatch of Loretta's hair to h friends.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 156
dialogues.text: She is in the throes of a migraine headache. She finds so pills, takes them, lies back and tries to sleep.  kt 157 158 159

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bus whines down the dark, endless highway....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo operates a backhoe making a drainage ditch at the of the yard; the twins ride with him. The bus passes on t road and turns up the driveway; Doo roars after it on backhoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus stops; Doo and the twins jump off the backhoe move to the bus. Loretta gets off, looking tired and Doo goes to her, the twins hang back.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Hi, baby. How you feelin'?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Tired. (sees Peggy) Hey, twin -- get over here and gimme a hug.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (sullen) My name ain't twin.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: When do you reckon I'm gonna be able to tell y'all apart?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Prob'ly never.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Y'all mind your manners or I'm gonna beat some little butts -- help Jim get Mama's stuff off the bus. They start for the house.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Got a lot to show you around here. Broke about fifty acres of that bottomland, ready for plantin'. Plus I finally got around to re- modellin' that kitchen -- wait'll you see what I done to it --- Inside the phone rings. Doo curses under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: How they know the minute you're home beats the hell outta me.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 157 158 foot the 159° and sick.  1f1 159 160

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED . 159
dialogues.text: He storms inside to the phone. The twins dart past with s of her luggage. She stops them.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Listen...Mama could tell y'all apart... ‘cept I'm just so tired.... They look at each other, turn and run into the house. Ins Doo is heard on the phone: "She just got home, give her a break, willya?" Etc. She stands looking at the house a mo then goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doll from the Sad-Faced Fan is on a shelf with dozens others. Loretta moves in and out of the bathroom getting for bed. Doo lounges, obviously hoping they'll make love tonight. He watches as she looks at her hair in the mirro

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You do somethin’ to your hair?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: This fan cut it for me.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Looks good. She gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You look skinny. You eatin' enough on the road?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: "Bout like usual, I been havin' my headaches like Daddy used to have.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You takin' anything for it?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: These pills. But they don't do no good. Ain't nothin' does no good. Just a family ailment, in our blood.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Maybe you orta slow down some.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: If you slow down, they forget about you. (starts for bed, sees him looking hopefully at her) I gotta rest, Doo.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I ain't gonna bother you. Don't worry. He turns and goes. She takes some sleeping pills, turns o light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the stream of the milldam is a row of spotlights: a gunshot; one explodes; another shot, another explodes...O bridge is Doo with a rifle, methodically shooting out the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo comes in with a bottle. The phone rings piercingly. Cursing he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: It's one o'clock in the mornin’ -- what the hell do you want? (listens; sighs) Loretta ain't here now, lady, she's on the road. How'd you get this number? (listens; shakes his head sadly; continues soothingly) Take it easy now, lady. Don't cry. I'll give Loretta your message. You liked her last album a lot. She loves you, too. She'll pray for you, too. Stop cryin', now, honey. Will you? Just stop cryin'...and get yourself some sleep. It'll be better in the mornin’. Naw, you didn't wake me up. What? Yeah, that's right, darlin’. It's a lots of lonesome people in this world. Good night, now.  kt 163

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta comes in in her bathrobe, sees Doo sleeping on th sofa in his clothes, the bottle nearby. She looks at him, disturbed. Hearing the twins outside, she looks out the window and sees them playing in the yard. Starts to go out when she sees a station wagon full of fans pulled up in the driveway, snapping pictures of the twins who blith ignore them. The fans spot her, she ducks back inside, th wave and shout enthusiastically. Doo stirs, gets up, come to the window. ~

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (wearily) I'll go tell 'em they ain't supposed to be up here...I swear I'm gonna build another damn house somewheres. Just let ‘em have this one.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Everything we got we owe them. Leave ‘em alone.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: We're the ones have to Live with it, not you. You ain't here long enough. A female fan outside keeps yelling "Loretta?" over and ov “Can you come out, Loretta?"

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Listen, Doo. I want you to come out on the road with me this time.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You know what happens when I get out on the road.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: It ain't just the road that's your problem. When I come in here this mornin', seen you a-layin' there like that...well, me and you gotta get together and see if we got anything left. Anyway, I need you out there. I'm gettin' run to death. The fan keeps calling: Suddenly she goes outside. Doo sta thoughtfully looking out the window as she smiles and pos with the twins.  kt 164 165 166 167 168

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo bursts through a stage entrance leading Loretta, the usual backstage throngs converge on her, reaching for her They move quickly through the backstage area to the wings of a large stage. They stop. She waits, poised as she's being introduced (by Don, the front man, onstage). Doo looks at her, but her concentration is on the audience. S enters, sweeping on stage, smiling, waving, become instan her public self. Flashbulbs explode, audience roars. Doo is left alone. He watches a moment as she begins a ne song. Then he begins to wander, nothing to do. Old trappe feeling comes over him. He heads for the stage door and o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the bus and gets on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bus empty except for two men at the drop-down table count money, which they deal into stacks of ones, fives, tens, twentys. Doo lies down and pulls his hat over his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta sings the new song, having trouble remembering th words. She turns to the leader, Dave, who calls out the lyrics to her. She goes on; stumbling, getting angry at herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo half-asleep looks up quickly as Loretta storms on ang says nothing, stalks straight back to her compartment. Musicians file on. Dave, the leader, quietly gives Doo a of quarter-inch tape.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Could you give this to her, Mooney? It's the new song, she had some trouble with the words tonight....

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (looks back at closed compartment) Yeah...I'll catch her with it later. Jim Webb begins moving the bus onto the road.  kt 169 170 171

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bus whooshes down the interstate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sleeps restlessly; shades are drawn; could be day or bus could be moving or stopped (should be the illusion th this scene is continuous with the previous one). She sudd ly jerks awake, peeks through curtains -- the bus is stop we are in anonymous, impersonal backstage area. A few fan see her and flash their cameras. She closes the curtains. Touches her head in pain.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doo. Doo? What time is it, Doo? No answer. She gets up and takes some pills for her heada Starts getting dressed when she sees the tape marked "new song." Starts to put it on her tape machine when she drop it -- and the tape spills out everywhere. Upset she tries rewind it, makes it worse.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doo? Doo! Is it time for me to go on? Her head is worse, she almost faints. Tangled in the tape she gets to her feet, can hardly stand. She opens the doo to the bus -- it's empty, dark.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doo! Doolittle...! Closes the door, sags back onto her bed, in great pain. S looks at the pill bottle -- can't remember whether she's any or not. Takes some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo coming down the corridor towards the stage door. Lore comes in, alone, her face looking drawn and sick.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I was just comin' to get you. You ready?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Where you been...You're supposed to take care of me....

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: That's what I'm doin', ain't it? Let's go. He hurries her down the corridor through the usual throng

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He escorts her to the edge of the stage; she is dazed, ne He doesn't see.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You learn that song?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What song...?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: That new song -- I give you the tape. You was supposed to learn it ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (upset) I don't know it, Doo -- I didn't learn it ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Take it easy. Drop it for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I can't sing tonight, Doo. Get somebody to tell ‘em,

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You can sing all right. Them people out there paid good money to hear you, You ain't gonna let ‘em down,

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I ain't gonna sing, Doo!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: You wanted me to come along to take care of you -- well, that's just what I'm gonna do, just like I always done when you get like this. I may not can do anything else for you anymore but I can sure as hell kick your rear end out there and make you sing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 172
dialogues.text: She looks at him, says nothing. A little smile comes on h lips. Onstage, Don the front man, begins his introduction.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (quietly) You listen good now, Doo...you gonna listen...?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Sure I'll listen... always do.... She goes onstage; Doo watches with a worried expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Coal Miners vamp the intro to the new song. She goes the mike, peers out: Flashbulbs explode in her face, as a The audience is a dark, inextinguishable presence. She mi her cue, band looks worried. She turns and stops them.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (in microphone) I had somethin’ I wanted to come out here and tell y'all tonight... but Doo, now he don't want me to say nothin', but...I can tell you, friends...see, things are a-movin' too fast in my life, always have, I mean, shoot, one day I was a little girl and the next day I was a wife and a mother and...one day I was a-keepin' house and the next day I was out here in ‘front of y'all...and Patsy, she's always sayin', little gal, you gotta run your own life, but...my life's a- runnin' me...and I.... Doo watches, helpless, from the wings. She stops talking, stares blankly out at the audience, which is absolutely silent, as if the hall were empty. Finally two band membe gently lead her to the wings. She looks at Doo as if he were a stranger, then collapses. He catches her, picks he up in his arms. Confusion all around: "Get a doctor!" “Bring her this way!" etc. Doo starts down the corridor, faster and faster until he is almost running. His eyes are filled with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: asleep, wakes up, looks around -- the dolls, the needlepo the pictures and fan-painted portraits of herself; finall twins standing at her bed, staring at her. She smiles, th smile, tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (to Peggy) How ya' doin’... (slight hesitation) Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Just fine, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: And how you doin', Patsy.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: That's Patsy -- I'm Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: That's the biggest lie -- she is too Patsy, Mama! Patsy laughs happily at her joke; both girls jump in bed Loretta hugs them happily.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Daddy says you gotta get up, right now.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Oh, he does, does he?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: . Yeah -- he says everybody's waitin' ---~

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Blabbermouth -- you're gonna ruin everthing!

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: What's goin' on here...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: comes out and sees a family reunion -- tables on the lawn covered dishes, mounds of food of all kinds. Clara, Doc Turner, the Coal Miners Band, other friends and neighbors

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mill 175 176

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 175
dialogues.text: and all her children, grown, including Betty Sue (and hus holding a baby. Loretta, touched, happy, hugs them all. D nowhere in sight.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY SUE
dialogues.text: (holding up baby to Loretta) Looks like Daddy, doesn't he, Mama? {to baby) . Can you say hi to your grandma?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (to baby) You better not call me grandma -- just Say Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: (worried) Are you gonna be all right now, honey?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I think so, Mommie. Doctor says I was just wore out and if I didn't slow down some I was gonna work my- self to death. That's what they said happened to Daddy, ain't it? Well, I ain't gonna let it happen to me. Where's Doolittle? Someone yells "Come and get it" and they all gather aroun tables. She looks around but can't spot Doo; then she see him ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amid the huge Belgian horses Doo is barely visible, leani against the stable in his dirty work clothes, watching. Loretta comes to the fence.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doo? Ain't you gonna eat? He looks at her, says nothing. Then climbs over the fence motions her to get in his jeep.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Come on with me. I wanna show you somethin’. She hesitates, but gets in. They drive off.  mll 177 178

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent, Doo drives down a gravel road, Loretta both curio and exasperated. Suddenly he turns off the road and goes cross-country up a wooded hill. She hangs on for life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: drives up and stops, they get out. A beautiful spot with vista of miles of woods and farmland. A small caterpillar with a grader sits nearby; signs of previous grading.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: It's real pretty...What are you up to, Doo?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I'm gonna build a new house here, for us to live in. Huliuva view, ain't -it? I picked this spot cause it's a little like Kentucky used to be. Loretta listens with growing disbelief, saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I'm gonna put the bedroom in the front of the house, see, right here, so we can wake up and look out and see the sun comin' up. Now, over here's gonna be the kitchen ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Doggone you, Doolittle Lynn! You never asked me nothin’ "bout no dog- gone house!

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I wanted to surprise you ~--

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Well, stop surprisin' me! Boy, you never ask me about nothin! -- never did -- you just say, Hey Baby, here's the deal, take it or leave’it ---

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: I thought vou'd want a new house -- for the privacy if nothin’ else ---

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I ain't said I don't want no new house ~- I just said you ain't asked me nothin' about it! Pause. Each stands silently smoldering. Loretta looks at ground plan.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You put the bedroom here, that daog- gone sun's gonna be shinin' in the window at five o'clock in the mornin! -- how'm I supposed to sleep?

dialogues.speaker: DOOLITTLE
dialogues.text: Well are you too ignorant to pull the damn window blinds down?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I ain't too ignorant to know you don't put the doggone bedroom in the front of the house -- that's where the doggone livin' room orta be! Impasse. Doo is growling.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Stop that growlin', Doo. He stops, glares at her, growls louder. She glares at him and growls back. He stops, surprised. They both look at each other, slowly smile. They shake their heads in wonde at the thought of two such ornery people still being toge They start for the jeep, Doo throws his arm around her, h her tightly. She continues to talk about the house as we cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sings "Coal Miner's Daughter." Doo listens backstage, smi sneaking a sip from a half-pint in his jacket. She contin the song until ---
